**Moscow** ^[\[a\]](#cite_note-14)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia_by_population "List of cities and towns in Russia by population") of [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"). The city stands on the [Moskva River](/wiki/Moskva_(river) "Moskva (river)") in [Central Russia](/wiki/Central_Russia "Central Russia"), with a population estimated at over 13 million residents within the city limits,^[\[6\]](#cite_note-2021Census-6)^ over 19.1 million residents in the urban area,^[\[7\]](#cite_note-Urban-7)^ and over 21.5 million residents in [its metropolitan area](/wiki/Moscow_metropolitan_area "Moscow metropolitan area").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Megapolis-15)^ The city covers an area of 2,511 square kilometers (970 sq mi), while the urban area covers 5,891 square kilometers (2,275 sq mi),^[\[7\]](#cite_note-Urban-7)^ and the metropolitan area covers over 26,000 square kilometers (10,000 sq mi).^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Megapolis-15)^ Moscow is among the world's [largest cities](/wiki/List_of_largest_cities "List of largest cities"), being the [most populous city](/wiki/List_of_European_cities_by_population_within_city_limits "List of European cities by population within city limits") in its entirety in Europe, the largest [urban](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_Europe "List of urban areas in Europe") and [metropolitan area](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe "List of metropolitan areas in Europe") in Europe,^[\[7\]](#cite_note-Urban-7)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Megapolis-15)^ and the largest city by land area on the European continent.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-Planète_Énergies-16)^{#cite_ref-Planète_Énergies_16-0}

First documented in 1147, Moscow grew to serve as the capital of the [Grand Duchy of Moscow](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow "Grand Duchy of Moscow"). When the [Tsardom of Russia](/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia "Tsardom of Russia") was proclaimed, Moscow remained the political and economic center for most of its history. Under the reign of [Peter the Great](/wiki/Peter_the_Great "Peter the Great"), the Russian capital was moved to the newly founded city of [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg") in 1712, decreasing Moscow's influence. Following the [Russian Revolution](/wiki/Russian_Revolution "Russian Revolution") and the establishment of the [Russian SFSR](/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic "Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic"), the capital was moved back to Moscow in 1918, where it later became the political center of the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union").^[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)^ In the aftermath of the [dissolution of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union"), Moscow remained the capital city of the newly established Russian Federation.{#cite_ref-17}

The northernmost and coldest [megacity](/wiki/Megacity "Megacity") in the world, Moscow is governed as a [federal city](/wiki/Federal_cities_of_Russia "Federal cities of Russia"),^[\[17\]](#cite_note-18)^ where it serves as the political, economic, cultural, and scientific center of Russia and [Eastern Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe"). As a [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city"),^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^ Moscow has one of the world's [largest urban economies](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP").^[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)^ The city is one of the fastest-growing tourist destinations^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^ and is one of Europe's [most visited cities](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_international_visitors "List of cities by international visitors"). Moscow has the [second-highest number of billionaires](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_number_of_billionaires "List of cities by number of billionaires") of any city (tied with [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong")).^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^ The [Moscow International Business Center](/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center "Moscow International Business Center") is one of the largest [financial centers](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") in the world and features the majority of [Europe's tallest skyscrapers](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Europe "List of tallest buildings in Europe"). Moscow was the host city of the [1980 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics") and one of the host cities of the [2018 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup").^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^{#cite_ref-23}

The city contains several UNESCO [World Heritage Sites](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") and is known for its display of [Russian architecture](/wiki/Russian_architecture "Russian architecture"), particularly in areas such as the [Red Square](/wiki/Red_Square "Red Square") and buildings such as the [Saint Basil's Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral "Saint Basil's Cathedral") and the [Moscow Kremlin](/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin "Moscow Kremlin"), the latter of which is the seat of power of the [Government of Russia](/wiki/Government_of_Russia "Government of Russia"). Moscow is home to [Russian companies](/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Russia "List of companies of Russia") in different industries and is served by a comprehensive transit network, which includes [four international airports](/wiki/Moscow_Airport_(disambiguation)#Commercial_passenger_and_cargo_traffic_airports "Moscow Airport (disambiguation)"), ten railway terminals, a [tram system](/wiki/Trams_in_Moscow "Trams in Moscow"), a [monorail system](/wiki/Moscow_Monorail "Moscow Monorail"), and the [Moscow Metro](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro"), which is the busiest metro system in Europe and one of the largest [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") systems in the world. The city has over 40 percent of its territory covered by greenery, making it one of the greenest cities in the world.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-Planète_Énergies-16)^^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^{#cite_ref-24}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

The city's name is thought to be derived from the [Moskva River](/wiki/Moskva_River "Moskva River").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Vasmer-25)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Smol-26)^ Theories of the origin of the name of the river have been proposed.{#cite_ref-Smol_26-0}

The most linguistically well-grounded and widely accepted is from the Proto-Balto-Slavic root \**mŭzg* -/*muzg* - from the [Proto-Indo-European](/wiki/Proto-Indo-European "Proto-Indo-European") \**meu* - "wet",^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Smol-26)^^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Trubach-27)^^[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)^ so the name *Moskva* might signify a river at a wetland or marsh.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Vasmer-25)^ Its [cognates](/wiki/Cognate "Cognate") include [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): музга, *muzga* "pool, puddle", [Lithuanian](/wiki/Lithuanian_language "Lithuanian language"): *mazgoti* and [Latvian](/wiki/Latvian_language "Latvian language"): *mazgāt* "to wash", [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit_language "Sanskrit language"): *májjati* "to drown", [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): *mergō* "to dip, immerse".^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Vasmer-25)^^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Trubach-27)^ In many Slavic countries Moskov is a surname, most common in Russia, [Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria "Bulgaria"), [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine") and [North Macedonia](/wiki/North_Macedonia "North Macedonia").^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^ Additionally, there are similarly named places in [Poland](/wiki/Poland "Poland") like [Mozgawa](/wiki/Mozgawa "Mozgawa").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Vasmer-25)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Smol-26)^^[\[26\]](#cite_note-Trubach-27)^ According to a [Finno-Ugric](/wiki/Finno-Ugric_languages "Finno-Ugric languages") hypothesis, the [Merya](/wiki/Volga_Finns "Volga Finns") and [Muroma](/wiki/Muromians "Muromians") people, who were among the pre-Slavic tribes which inhabited the area, called the river *Mustajoki* "Black river", and the name of the river derives from this term.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^ Other theories, having little or no scientific basis, are rejected by linguists.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Vasmer-25)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Smol-26)^{#cite_ref-Smol_26-3}

The original [Old Russian](/wiki/Old_East_Slavic "Old East Slavic") form of the name is reconstructed as \*Москы, \**Mosky*,^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Vasmer-25)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Smol-26)^ hence it was one of a few Slavic [*ū*-stem nouns](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Proto-Slavic_v-stem_nouns "wikt:Category:Proto-Slavic v-stem nouns"). As with other nouns of that declension, it had been undergoing a morphological transformation at the early stage of the development of the language, as a result, the first written references in the 12th century were Московь, *Moskovĭ* ([accusative case](/wiki/Accusative_case "Accusative case")), Москви, *Moskvi* ([locative case](/wiki/Locative_case "Locative case")), Москвe/Москвѣ, *Moskve/Moskvě* ([genitive case](/wiki/Genitive_case "Genitive case")).^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Vasmer-25)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Smol-26)^ From the latter forms came the modern Russian name Москва, *Moskva*, which is a result of [morphological generalization](/wiki/Morphological_leveling "Morphological leveling") with the numerous Slavic [*ā*-stem nouns](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Proto-Slavic_hard_a-stem_nouns "wikt:Category:Proto-Slavic hard a-stem nouns"). The form *Moskovĭ* has left traces in other languages, including English: Moscow; [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"): *Moskau* ;^[\[30\]](#cite_note-31)^ [French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): *Moscou* ;^[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)^ [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): *Moscou, Moscovo* ;^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^ and [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"): *Moscú* .^[\[33\]](#cite_note-34)^{#cite_ref-34}

Moscow has acquired [epithets](/wiki/Epithet "Epithet"), such as The *[Third Rome](/wiki/Moscow,_third_Rome "Moscow, third Rome")* .^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^ Moscow is one of twelve [Hero Cities](/wiki/Hero_City_(Soviet_Union) "Hero City (Soviet Union)").^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^ The [demonym](/wiki/Demonym "Demonym") for a Moscow resident is rendered as *Muscovite* in English.{#cite_ref-36}  

History {#History}
------------------

Main article: [History of Moscow](/wiki/History_of_Moscow "History of Moscow")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Moscow](/wiki/Timeline_of_Moscow "Timeline of Moscow").  

### Prehistory {#Prehistory}

The site of modern-day Moscow has been inhabited since prehistoric times. Among the earliest finds are relics of the [Lyalovo culture](/w/index.php?title=Lyalovo_culture&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lyalovo culture (page does not exist)"), which experts assign to the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") period.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ They confirm that the first inhabitants of the area were hunters and gatherers. Around 950 AD, two Slavic tribes, [Vyatichi](/wiki/Vyatichi "Vyatichi") and [Krivichi](/wiki/Krivichi "Krivichi"), settled here. The Vyatichi may have formed the majority of Moscow's indigenous population.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^{#cite_ref-38}  

### Early history (1147--1284) {#Early_history_.281147.E2.80.931284.29}

Further information: [Kievan Rus'](/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27 "Kievan Rus'") and [Vladimir-Suzdal](/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal "Vladimir-Suzdal")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Kyivan_Rus%27_1220-1240.png/180px-Kyivan_Rus%27_1220-1240.png)](/wiki/File:Kyivan_Rus%27_1220-1240.png) [Vladimir-Suzdal](/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal "Vladimir-Suzdal"), a principality on the northeastern periphery of [Kievan Rus'](/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27 "Kievan Rus'"), grew into the Grand Duchy of Moscow.

The first known reference to Moscow was in 1147, as a meeting place of [Yuri Dolgorukiy](/wiki/Yuri_Dolgorukiy "Yuri Dolgorukiy") and [Sviatoslav Olgovich](/wiki/Sviatoslav_Olgovich "Sviatoslav Olgovich"). At the time it was a minor town on the western border of Vladimir-Suzdal Principality.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^ In 1156, Dolgorukiy fortified the town by creating a wooden wall; this structure became the Kremlin.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^ In the course of the [Mongol invasion of Kievan Rus'](/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Kievan_Rus%27 "Mongol invasion of Kievan Rus'"), the Mongols under [Batu Khan](/wiki/Batu_Khan "Batu Khan") burned the city to the ground and killed its inhabitants.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-40}

The timber fort *na Moskvě* "on the Moscow River" was inherited by [Daniel](/wiki/Daniel_of_Moscow "Daniel of Moscow"), the youngest son of [Alexander Nevsky](/wiki/Alexander_Nevsky "Alexander Nevsky"), in the 1260s. Daniel was still a child at the time, and the large fort was governed by *tiuns* (deputies), appointed by Daniel's paternal uncle, [Yaroslav of Tver](/wiki/Yaroslav_of_Tver "Yaroslav of Tver").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Daniel came of age in the 1270s and became involved in the power struggles of the principality with lasting success, siding with his brother [Dmitry](/wiki/Dmitry_of_Pereslavl "Dmitry of Pereslavl") in his bid for the rule of [Novgorod](/wiki/Novgorod "Novgorod"). From 1283 he acted as the ruler of an independent principality alongside Dmitry, who became [Grand Duke of Vladimir](/wiki/Grand_Duke_of_Vladimir "Grand Duke of Vladimir"). Daniel has been credited with founding the first Moscow monasteries, dedicated to the Lord's Epiphany and to Saint Daniel.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}  

### Grand Duchy (1283--1547) {#Grand_Duchy_.281283.E2.80.931547.29}

Main article: [Grand Duchy of Moscow](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow "Grand Duchy of Moscow")

Daniel ruled Moscow as Grand Duke until 1303 and established it as a prosperous city that would eclipse its parent principality of Vladimir by the 1320s. On the right bank of the Moskva River, at a distance of eight kilometres (5 mi) from the Kremlin, by 1282 Daniel founded the first monastery with the wooden church of St. Daniel-Stylite, which is now the Danilov Monastery. Daniel died in 1303, aged 42. Before his death, he became a monk and, according to his will, was buried in the cemetery of the St. Daniel Monastery.

Moscow was stable and prosperous for many years and attracted refugees from across Russia. The Rurikids maintained large landholdings by practicing [primogeniture](/wiki/Primogeniture "Primogeniture"), whereby all land was passed to the eldest sons. By 1304, [Yury of Moscow](/wiki/Yury_of_Moscow "Yury of Moscow") contested with [Mikhail of Tver](/wiki/Mikhail_of_Tver "Mikhail of Tver") for the throne of the principality of [Vladimir](/wiki/Vladimir,_Russia "Vladimir, Russia"). [Ivan I](/wiki/Ivan_I_of_Russia "Ivan I of Russia") eventually defeated [Tver](/wiki/Tver "Tver") to become the sole collector of taxes for the [Mongol](/wiki/Mongol "Mongol") rulers, making Moscow the capital of [Vladimir-Suzdal](/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal "Vladimir-Suzdal"). By paying high tribute, Ivan won an important concession from the [Khan](/wiki/Khan_(title) "Khan (title)").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8E_%D0%BE%D1%82_%D0%98%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D1%8F.jpg/150px-%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8E_%D0%BE%D1%82_%D0%98%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D1%8F.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8E_%D0%BE%D1%82_%D0%98%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D1%8F.jpg) The [Spasskaya Tower](/wiki/Spasskaya_Tower "Spasskaya Tower"), built in 1491

While the Khan of the [Golden Horde](/wiki/Golden_Horde "Golden Horde") initially attempted to limit Moscow's influence, when the growth of the [Grand Duchy of Lithuania](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania "Grand Duchy of Lithuania") began to threaten all of Russia, the Khan strengthened Moscow to counterbalance Lithuania, allowing it to become one of the most powerful cities in Russia. In 1380, prince [Dmitry Donskoy](/wiki/Dmitry_Donskoy "Dmitry Donskoy") of Moscow led a united Russian army to an important victory over the Mongols in the [Battle of Kulikovo](/wiki/Battle_of_Kulikovo "Battle of Kulikovo"). Afterward, Moscow took the leading role in liberating Russia from Mongol domination. In 1480, [Ivan III](/wiki/Ivan_III_of_Russia "Ivan III of Russia") had [finally broken the Russians free](/wiki/Great_standing_on_the_Ugra_river "Great standing on the Ugra river") from [Tatar](/wiki/Tatars "Tatars") control, and Moscow became the capital of an empire that would eventually encompass all of Russia and [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia"), and parts of many other lands.

In 1462 Ivan III became Grand Prince of Moscow (then part of the medieval Muscovy state). He began fighting the Tatars, enlarged the territory of Muscovy, and enriched his capital city. By 1500 it had a population of 100,000 and was one of the largest cities in the world. He conquered the far larger principality of Novgorod to the north, which had been allied to the hostile Lithuanians. Thus he enlarged the territory sevenfold, from 430,000 to 2,800,000 square kilometres (170,000 to 1,080,000 square miles). He took control of the ancient "[Novgorod Chronicle](/wiki/Novgorod_Chronicle "Novgorod Chronicle")" and made it a propaganda vehicle for his regime.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^^[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)^{#cite_ref-43}

The original [Moscow Kremlin](/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin "Moscow Kremlin") was built in the 14th century. It was reconstructed by Ivan, who in the 1480s invited architects from [Renaissance Italy](/wiki/Renaissance_Italy "Renaissance Italy"), such as [Petrus Antonius Solarius](/wiki/Petrus_Antonius_Solarius "Petrus Antonius Solarius"), who designed the new Kremlin wall and its towers, and [Marco Ruffo](/wiki/Marco_Ruffo "Marco Ruffo") who designed the new palace for the prince. The Kremlin walls as they now appear are those designed by Solarius, completed in 1495. The Kremlin's Great Bell Tower was built in 1505--08 and augmented to its present height in 1600. A trading settlement, or *posad* , grew up to the east of the Kremlin, in the area known as *Zaradye* . In the time of Ivan III, the [Red Square](/wiki/Red_Square "Red Square"), originally named the Hollow Field appeared.

In 1508--1516, the Italian architect [Aleviz Fryazin (Novy)](/wiki/Aloisio_the_New "Aloisio the New") arranged for the construction of a moat in front of the eastern wall, which would connect the [Moskva](/wiki/Moskva_River "Moskva River") and [Neglinnaya](/wiki/Neglinnaya_River "Neglinnaya River") and be filled with water from Neglinnaya. Known as the Alevizov moat and with a length of 541 metres (1,775 feet), width of 36 metres (118 feet), and depth of 9.5 to 13 metres (31--43 feet) was lined with limestone and, in 1533, fenced on both sides with low, four-metre-thick (13-foot) cogged-brick walls.{#Tsardom}  

### Tsardom (1547--1721) {#Tsardom_.281547.E2.80.931721.29}

Further information: [Tsardom of Russia](/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia "Tsardom of Russia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d28.jpg/180px-Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d28.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d28.jpg) [Saint Basil's Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral "Saint Basil's Cathedral"), built in 1561

In the 16th and 17th centuries, three circular defenses were built: [Kitay-gorod](/wiki/Kitay-gorod "Kitay-gorod"), the White City and the Earthen City. However, in 1547, fires destroyed much of the town, and in 1571 the [Crimean Tatars](/wiki/Crimean_Tatars "Crimean Tatars") [captured Moscow](/wiki/Russo-Crimean_Wars "Russo-Crimean Wars"), burning everything except the Kremlin.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)^ The annals record that only 30,000 of 200,000 inhabitants survived.{#cite_ref-44}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Polish_plan_of_Moscow_1610.PNG/220px-Polish_plan_of_Moscow_1610.PNG)](/wiki/File:Polish_plan_of_Moscow_1610.PNG) "Sigismundian" Plan of Moscow (1610), before the city's destruction in 1612 and changes to streets. North is to the right.

The [Crimean Tatars](/wiki/Khanate_of_Crimea "Khanate of Crimea") attacked again in 1591, but were held back by new walls, built between 1584 and 1591 by a craftsman named [Fyodor Kon](/wiki/Fyodor_Kon "Fyodor Kon"). In 1592, an outer earth rampart with 50 towers was erected around the city, including an area on the right bank of the Moscow River. As an outermost line of defense, a chain of strongly fortified monasteries was established beyond the ramparts to the south and east, principally the [Novodevichy Convent](/wiki/Novodevichy_Convent "Novodevichy Convent") and [Donskoy](/wiki/Donskoy_Monastery "Donskoy Monastery"), [Danilov](/wiki/Danilov_Monastery "Danilov Monastery"), [Simonov](/wiki/Simonov_Monastery "Simonov Monastery"), [Novospasskiy](/wiki/Novospassky_Monastery "Novospassky Monastery"), and [Andronikov](/wiki/Andronikov_Monastery "Andronikov Monastery") monasteries, most of which now house museums. From its ramparts, the city became poetically known as *Bielokamennaya* , the "White-Walled". The city's limits as marked by the ramparts, are now marked by the [Garden Ring](/wiki/Garden_Ring "Garden Ring"). Three square gates existed on the east side of the Kremlin wall, which in the 17th century, were known as Konstantino-Eleninsky, Spassky, Nikolsky (after the icons of Constantine and Helen, the Saviour and St. Nicholas that hung over them). The last two were directly opposite the Red Square, while the Konstantino-Elenensky gate was located behind Saint Basil's Cathedral.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

The [Russian famine of 1601--03](/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1601%E2%80%9303 "Russian famine of 1601–03") killed perhaps 100,000 in Moscow. Between 1610 and 1612, troops of the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth") occupied Moscow, as its ruler [Sigismund III](/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa "Sigismund III Vasa") tried to take the Russian throne. In 1612, [Nizhny Novgorod](/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod "Nizhny Novgorod") and other Russian cities led by prince [Dmitry Pozharsky](/wiki/Dmitry_Pozharsky "Dmitry Pozharsky") and [Kuzma Minin](/wiki/Kuzma_Minin "Kuzma Minin") rose against the Polish occupants, [besieged the Kremlin, and expelled them](/wiki/Time_of_Troubles "Time of Troubles"). In 1613, the [Zemsky Sobor](/wiki/Zemsky_Sobor "Zemsky Sobor") elected [Michael Romanov](/wiki/Michael_I_of_Russia "Michael I of Russia") tsar, establishing the [Romanov dynasty](/wiki/Romanov_dynasty "Romanov dynasty"). The 17th century saw several risings, such as the liberation of Moscow from the Polish--Lithuanian invaders (1612), the [Salt Riot](/wiki/Salt_Riot "Salt Riot") (1648), the [Copper Riot](/wiki/Copper_Riot "Copper Riot") (1662), and the [Moscow Uprising of 1682](/wiki/Moscow_Uprising_of_1682 "Moscow Uprising of 1682").

During the first half of the 17th century, the population doubled from 100,000 to 200,000, and it expanded beyond its ramparts in the latter part of the century. In the middle of the 17th century, 20% of Moscow suburb's inhabitants were from the [Grand Duchy of Lithuania](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania "Grand Duchy of Lithuania"), being driven from their homeland by Muscovite invaders.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^ By 1682, there were 692 households established north of the ramparts, by [Ukrainians](/wiki/Ukrainians "Ukrainians") and [Belarusians](/wiki/Belarusians "Belarusians") abducted from their hometowns in the course of the [Russo-Polish War (1654--1667)](/wiki/Russo-Polish_War_(1654%E2%80%931667) "Russo-Polish War (1654–1667)"). These new outskirts became known as the *Meshchanskaya [sloboda](/wiki/Sloboda_(settlement) "Sloboda (settlement)")* , after Ruthenian *meshchane* "town people". The term *meshchane* acquired pejorative connotations in 18th-century Russia and today means "petty bourgeois" or "narrow-minded philistine".^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^ The entire city of the late 17th century are contained within what is today Moscow's [Central Administrative Okrug](/wiki/Central_Administrative_Okrug "Central Administrative Okrug").{#cite_ref-46}

Numerous disasters befell the city. The [plague](/wiki/Black_Death "Black Death") epidemics ravaged Moscow in 1570--1571, 1592 and 1654--1656.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^ The plague killed upwards of 80% of the people in 1654--55. Fires burned out much of the wooden city in 1626 and 1648.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^ In 1712 [Peter the Great](/wiki/Peter_the_Great "Peter the Great") moved his government to the newly built [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg") on the Baltic coast.{#cite_ref-48}  

### Empire (1721--1917) {#Empire_.281721.E2.80.931917.29}

Main article: [Moscow Governorate](/wiki/Moscow_Governorate "Moscow Governorate")  
Further information: [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire")  
[![Panorama of Moscow in 1819-1823](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D1%8B_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%BB%D1%8F.jpg/1961px-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D1%8B_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%BB%D1%8F.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D1%8B_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%BB%D1%8F.jpg "A panoramic view of Moscow from the Spasskaya Tower in 1819–1823")  
[](/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D1%8B_%D1%81%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%BB%D1%8F.jpg "File:Круговая панорама Москвы со Спасской башни Кремля.jpg")  
A [panoramic](/wiki/Panorama "Panorama") view of Moscow from the [Spasskaya Tower](/wiki/Spasskaya_Tower "Spasskaya Tower") in 1819--1823

After losing the status as capital, the population at first decreased, from 200,000 in the 17th century to 130,000 in 1750. But after 1750, the population grew tenfold over the remaining duration of the Russian Empire, reaching 1.8 million by 1915. The [1770--1772 Russian plague](/wiki/1770%E2%80%931772_Russian_plague "1770–1772 Russian plague") killed up to 100,000 people in Moscow.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^ By 1700, the building of cobbled roads had begun. In 1730, permanent street lights were introduced, and by 1867 many streets had a gaslight. In 1883, near the Prechistinskiye Gates, arc lamps were installed. In 1741 Moscow was surrounded by a barricade 40 kilometres (25 mi) long, the Kamer-Kollezhskiy barrier, with 16 gates at which customs tolls were collected. Its line is traced today by several streets called *val* ("ramparts"). In the early 19th century, the Arch of Konstantino-Elenensky gate was paved with bricks, but the Spassky Gate was the main front gate of the Kremlin and used for royal entrances. From this gate, wooden and stone bridges stretched across the moat. Books were sold on this bridge and stone platforms were built nearby for guns -- "raskats". The [Tsar Cannon](/wiki/Tsar_Cannon "Tsar Cannon") was located on the platform of the [Lobnoye mesto](/wiki/Lobnoye_mesto "Lobnoye mesto"). The road connecting Moscow with St. Petersburg, now the [M10 highway](/wiki/M10_highway_(Russia) "M10 highway (Russia)"), was completed in 1746, its Moscow end following the old [Tver](/wiki/Tver "Tver") road, which had existed since the 16th century. It became known as *[Peterburskoye Schosse](/wiki/Leningradsky_Prospekt "Leningradsky Prospekt")* after it was paved in the 1780s. [Petrovsky Palace](/wiki/Petrovsky_Palace "Petrovsky Palace") was built in 1776--1780 by [Matvey Kazakov](/wiki/Matvey_Kazakov "Matvey Kazakov"). Between 1781 and 1804 the Mytischinskiy water pipe (the first in Russia) was built.{#cite_ref-49}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Fireofmoscow.jpg/220px-Fireofmoscow.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fireofmoscow.jpg) Napoleon retreating during the [Fire of Moscow](/wiki/Fire_of_Moscow_(1812) "Fire of Moscow (1812)"), after the failed [French invasion](/wiki/French_invasion_of_Russia "French invasion of Russia") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Moscou._Le_Kremlin_LOC_ppmsca.52725.jpg/220px-Moscou._Le_Kremlin_LOC_ppmsca.52725.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscou._Le_Kremlin_LOC_ppmsca.52725.jpg) [Moskva](/wiki/Moskva_(river) "Moskva (river)") riverfront in the 19th century

When [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France "Napoleon I of France") [invaded](/wiki/Napoleon%27s_invasion_of_Russia "Napoleon's invasion of Russia") Russia in 1812, the Moscovites were evacuated. The [Moscow fire](/wiki/Fire_of_Moscow_(1812) "Fire of Moscow (1812)") was principally the effect of Russian sabotage. Napoleon's *[Grande Armée](/wiki/Grande_Arm%C3%A9e "Grande Armée")* was forced to retreat and nearly annihilated by the devastating Russian winter. In 1813, following the destruction during the French occupation, a *Commission for the Construction of the City of Moscow* was established. It launched a great program of rebuilding, including a partial replanning of the centre. Among many buildings constructed, or reconstructed, was the [Grand Kremlin Palace](/wiki/Grand_Kremlin_Palace "Grand Kremlin Palace") and the [Kremlin Armoury](/wiki/Kremlin_Armoury "Kremlin Armoury"), the [Moscow University](/wiki/Moscow_University "Moscow University"), the [Moscow Manege](/wiki/Moscow_Manege "Moscow Manege") (Riding School), and the [Bolshoi Theatre](/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre "Bolshoi Theatre"). The [Arbat Street](/wiki/Arbat_Street "Arbat Street") had been in existence since at least the 15th century, but it was developed into a prestigious area during the 18th century. It was destroyed in the fire of 1812 and was rebuilt completely in the early 19th century. [Moscow State University](/wiki/Moscow_State_University "Moscow State University") was established in 1755. Its main building was reconstructed after the 1812 fire by [Domenico Giliardi](/wiki/Domenico_Giliardi "Domenico Giliardi"). The *[Moskovskiye Vedomosti](/wiki/Moskovskiye_Vedomosti "Moskovskiye Vedomosti")* newspaper appeared from 1756, originally in weekly intervals, and from 1859 as a daily newspaper.

In the 1830s, general [Alexander Bashilov](/wiki/Alexander_Bashilov "Alexander Bashilov") planned the first regular grid of city streets north from Petrovsky Palace. [Khodynka field](/wiki/Khodynka_Field "Khodynka Field") south of the highway was used for military training. Smolensky Rail station (forerunner of [Belorussky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Belorussky_Rail_Terminal "Belorussky Rail Terminal")) was inaugurated in 1870. [Sokolniki Park](/wiki/Sokolniki_Park "Sokolniki Park"), in the 18th century the home of the tsar's falconers well outside Moscow, became contiguous with the expanding city in the later 19th century and was developed into a public municipal park in 1878. The suburban [Savyolovsky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Savyolovsky_Rail_Terminal "Savyolovsky Rail Terminal") was built in 1902. In January 1905, the institution of the City Governor, or [Mayor](/wiki/Mayor "Mayor"), was officially introduced, and Alexander Adrianov became Moscow's first official mayor.

When [Catherine II](/wiki/Catherine_the_Great "Catherine the Great") came to power in 1762, the city's filth and the smell of sewage were depicted by observers as a symptom of disorderly lifestyles of lower-class Russians recently arrived from the farms. Elites called for improved sanitation, which became part of Catherine's plans for increasing control over social life. National political and military successes from 1812 through 1855 calmed the critics and validated efforts to produce a more enlightened and stable society. There was less discussion about the poor conditions of public health. However, in the wake of Russia's failures in the Crimean War in 1855--56, confidence in the ability of the state to maintain order in the slums eroded, and demands for improved public health put it back on the agenda.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^ In 1903 the Moskvoretskaya water supply was completed.{#cite_ref-50}  

### Soviet period (1917--1991) {#Soviet_period_.281917.E2.80.931991.29}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Plan_of_Moscow_1917.jpg/150px-Plan_of_Moscow_1917.jpg)](/wiki/File:Plan_of_Moscow_1917.jpg) City plan of Moscow, 1917

In November 1917, upon learning of [the uprising in Petrograd](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution"), Moscow's [Bolsheviks](/wiki/Bolsheviks "Bolsheviks") [began their uprising](/wiki/Moscow_Bolshevik_Uprising "Moscow Bolshevik Uprising"). On 2 November (15), 1917, after heavy fighting, [Soviet power](/wiki/Soviet_power "Soviet power") was established in Moscow.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^ [Vladimir Lenin](/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin "Vladimir Lenin"), fearing invasion, moved the capital back to Moscow on 12 March 1918.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-prlib-52)^ The Kremlin once again became the seat of power, political centre of the new state.{#cite_ref-prlib_52-0}

With the [change in values imposed by communist ideology](/wiki/Russian_cultural_heritage_register#Denial_of_heritage_(1917–1941) "Russian cultural heritage register"), the tradition of preserving cultural heritage was broken. Independent preservation societies, even those that defended only secular landmarks, were disbanded by the end of the 1920s. A new anti-religious campaign, launched in 1929, coincided with the collectivization of peasants; the destruction of churches in the cities peaked around 1932. In 1937 letters were written to the [Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union") to rename Moscow to "Stalindar" or "Stalinodar".^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^ Stalin rejected this suggestion.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-54)^{#cite_ref-54}

During World War II, the Soviet State Committee of Defence and the General Staff of the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") were located in Moscow. In 1941, 16 divisions of the national volunteers (more than 160,000 people), 25 battalions, and 4 engineering regiments were formed among the Muscovites. Between October 1941 and January 1942, the German [Army Group Centre](/wiki/Army_Group_Centre "Army Group Centre") was stopped at the outskirts of the city, then driven off in the [Battle of Moscow](/wiki/Battle_of_Moscow "Battle of Moscow"). Many factories were evacuated, together with much of the government, and from 20 October the city was declared to be in a siege. Its remaining inhabitants built and manned antitank defenses, while the city was bombarded from the air. On 1 May 1944, a medal "For the defence of Moscow" and in 1947 another medal "In memory of the 800th anniversary of Moscow" was instituted. [German](/wiki/German_casualties_in_World_War_II "German casualties in World War II") and [Soviet casualties](/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union "World War II casualties of the Soviet Union") during the battle have been debated, as sources provide different estimates. Total casualties between 30 September 1941, and 7 January 1942, are estimated to be between 248,000 and 400,000 for the [Wehrmacht](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht") and between 650,000 and 1,280,000 for the Red Army.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^^[\[56\]](#cite_note-57)^{#cite_ref-57}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Stalin%27s_funeral_procession_entering_Manezhnaya_Square_from_Okhotny_Ryad.jpg/220px-Stalin%27s_funeral_procession_entering_Manezhnaya_Square_from_Okhotny_Ryad.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stalin%27s_funeral_procession_entering_Manezhnaya_Square_from_Okhotny_Ryad.jpg) Stalin's funeral procession, 1953

| External videos ||
|---|---|
| ![video icon](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/16px-Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png) [Stalin's Moscow in 1953](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9p20dxtTkY) ||

During the postwar years, there was a housing crisis, solved by the invention of [high-rise apartments](/wiki/Tower_block "Tower block"). There are over 11,000 of these standardised and prefabricated apartment blocks, housing most of Moscow's population, making it by far the city with the most high-rise buildings.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-hrranking-58)^ Apartments were built and partly furnished in the factory, before being raised and stacked into tall columns. The popular Soviet-era comic film *[Irony of Fate](/wiki/Irony_of_Fate "Irony of Fate")* parodies this construction method. The city of [Zelenograd](/wiki/Zelenograd "Zelenograd") was built in 1958 at 37 kilometres (23 miles) from the city centre to the north-west, along with the [Leningradskoye Shosse](/wiki/Leningradskoye_Shosse "Leningradskoye Shosse"), and incorporated as one of Moscow's [administrative okrugs](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Moscow "Administrative divisions of Moscow"). [Moscow State University](/wiki/Moscow_State_University "Moscow State University") moved to its campus on [Sparrow Hills](/wiki/Sparrow_Hills "Sparrow Hills") in 1953.{#cite_ref-hrranking_58-0}

In 1959 Nikita Khrushchev launched [his anti-religious campaign](/wiki/Russian_cultural_heritage_register#Khrushchev's_offensive_(1959–1964) "Russian cultural heritage register"). Of Moscow's fifty churches operating in 1959, thirty were closed and six demolished. On 8 May 1965, due to the actual 20th [anniversary of the victory](/wiki/Victory_Day_(9_May) "Victory Day (9 May)") in World War II, Moscow was awarded a title of the [Hero City](/wiki/Hero_City_(Soviet_Union) "Hero City (Soviet Union)").

The [Moscow Ring Road](/wiki/Moscow_Ring_Road "Moscow Ring Road") (MKAD) was opened in 1961. It had four lanes running 109 kilometres (68 miles) along the city borders. The MKAD marked the administrative boundaries of the city until the 1980s, when outlying suburbs beyond the ring road were incorporated. In 1980, Moscow hosted the [Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics"), which were boycotted by the US and other Western countries due to the Soviet Union's invasion of [Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan "Afghanistan") in 1979. In 1991 Moscow was the scene of a [coup attempt](/wiki/Soviet_coup_attempt_of_1991 "Soviet coup attempt of 1991") by conservative communists opposed to the [liberal reforms](/wiki/Perestroika "Perestroika") of [Mikhail Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Gorbachev").  

### 1991--present {#1991.E2.80.93present}

When the USSR was dissolved in 1991, Moscow remained the capital of the [Russian Federation](/wiki/Russian_Federation "Russian Federation"). Since then, a market economy has emerged, producing an explosion of Western-style retailing, services, architecture, and lifestyles. The city continued to grow during the 1990s to 2000s, its population rising from below nine to above ten million. Mason and Nigmatullina argue that Soviet-era urban-growth controls produced controlled and sustainable metropolitan development, typified by the greenbelt built in 1935. Since then, however, there has been a dramatic growth of low-density suburban sprawl, created by heavy demand for single-family dwellings as opposed to crowded apartments. In 1995--97 the MKAD ring road was widened from the initial four to ten lanes.

In December 2002 [Bulvar Dmitriya Donskogo](/wiki/Bulvar_Dmitriya_Donskogo "Bulvar Dmitriya Donskogo") became the first Moscow Metro station that opened beyond the limits of MKAD. The [Third Ring Road](/wiki/Third_Ring_Road_(Moscow) "Third Ring Road (Moscow)"), intermediate between the early 19th-century [Garden Ring](/wiki/Garden_Ring "Garden Ring") and the Soviet-era outer ring road, was completed in 2004. The greenbelt is becoming more and more fragmented, and satellite cities are appearing at the fringe. Summer dachas are being converted into year-round residences, and with the proliferation of automobiles there is heavy traffic congestion.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^ Multiple old churches and other examples of architectural heritage that had been demolished during the Stalin era have been restored, such as the [Cathedral of Christ the Saviour](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour "Cathedral of Christ the Saviour"). In 2010s Moscow's Administration has launched some long duration projects like the *Moja Ulitsa* (in English: *My Street* ) urban redevelopment program^[\[59\]](#cite_note-60)^ or the Residency renovation one.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-61)^{#cite_ref-61}

By its territorial expansion on 1 July 2012, southwest into the [Moscow Oblast](/wiki/Moscow_Oblast "Moscow Oblast") the area of the capital more than doubled, going from 1,091 to 2,511 square kilometers (421 to 970 sq mi), resulting in Moscow becoming the largest city on the European continent by area; it also gained an additional population of 233,000 people.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-Merger2-62)^^[\[62\]](#cite_note-Mos.ru-63)^ The annexed territory was officially named *Новая Москва* (New Moscow).{#cite_ref-Mos.ru_63-0}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

### Location {#Location}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Moscow_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-11.jpg/220px-Moscow_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-11.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_by_Sentinel-2,_2020-05-11.jpg) Satellite view of Moscow and its nearby suburbs

Moscow is situated on the banks of the [Moskva River](/wiki/Moskva_River "Moskva River"), which flows for just over 500 km (311 mi) through the [East European Plain](/wiki/East_European_Plain "East European Plain") in central Russia, not far from the natural border of the forest and forest-[steppe](/wiki/Steppe "Steppe") zone. [49 bridges](/wiki/List_of_bridges_in_Moscow "List of bridges in Moscow") span the river and its canals within the city's limits. The [elevation](/wiki/Elevation "Elevation") of Moscow at the All-Russia Exhibition Center (VVC), where the leading Moscow weather station is situated, is 156 metres (512 feet). [Teplostan Upland](/wiki/Teplostan_Upland "Teplostan Upland") is the city's highest point at 255 metres (837 feet).^[\[63\]](#cite_note-64)^ The width of Moscow city (not limiting [MKAD](/wiki/MKAD "MKAD")) from west to east is 39.7 km (24.7 mi), and the length from north to south is 51.8 km (32.2 mi).{#cite_ref-64}  

### Time {#Time}

Main article: [Moscow Time](/wiki/Moscow_Time "Moscow Time")

Moscow serves as the reference point for the time zone used in most of [European Russia](/wiki/European_Russia "European Russia"), [Belarus](/wiki/Belarus "Belarus") and the [Republic of Crimea](/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea_(Russia) "Republic of Crimea (Russia)"). The areas operate in what is referred to in international standards as *Moscow Standard Time (MSK, МСК)* , which is 3 hours ahead of [UTC](/wiki/UTC "UTC"), or [UTC+3](/wiki/UTC%2B3 "UTC+3"). [Daylight saving time](/wiki/Daylight_saving_time "Daylight saving time") is no longer observed. According to the geographical [longitude](/wiki/Longitude "Longitude") the average [solar noon](/wiki/Solar_noon "Solar noon") in Moscow occurs at 12:30.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-65)^{#cite_ref-65}  

### Climate {#Climate}

Main article: [Climate of Moscow](/wiki/Climate_of_Moscow "Climate of Moscow")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Moscow%2C_VDNKh%2C_Central_Alley_after_rain_%2830580970263%29.jpg/220px-Moscow%2C_VDNKh%2C_Central_Alley_after_rain_%2830580970263%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow,_VDNKh,_Central_Alley_after_rain_(30580970263).jpg) [VDNKh](/wiki/Exhibition_of_Achievements_of_National_Economy "Exhibition of Achievements of National Economy") after rain

Moscow has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Dfb* ) with long, cold (although average by Russian standards) winters usually lasting from mid-November to the end of March, and warm summers. More extreme continental climates at the same latitude -- such as parts of [Eastern Canada](/wiki/Eastern_Canada "Eastern Canada") or [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia") -- have much colder winters than Moscow, suggesting that there is still significant moderation from the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean")^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ despite the fact that Moscow is far from the sea. Weather can fluctuate widely, with temperatures ranging from −25 °C (−13 °F) in the city and −30 °C (−22 °F) in the suburbs to above 5 °C (41 °F) in the winter, and from 10 to 35 °C (50 to 95 °F) in the summer.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-66)^{#cite_ref-66}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86_%28%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B0%2C_2018%29.jpg/170px-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86_%28%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B0%2C_2018%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86_(%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B0,_2018).jpg) [Petrovsky Palace](/wiki/Petrovsky_Palace "Petrovsky Palace") on [Leningradsky Avenue](/wiki/Leningradsky_Avenue "Leningradsky Avenue") in winter

Typical high temperatures in the warm months of June, July, and August are around a comfortable 20 to 26 °C (68 to 79 °F), but during heat waves (which can occur between May and September), daytime high temperatures often exceed 30 °C (86 °F), sometimes for a week or two at a time. In the winter, average temperatures normally drop to approximately −10 °C (14 °F), though almost every winter there are periods of warmth with day temperatures rising above 0 °C (32 °F), and periods of cooling with night temperatures falling below −20 °C (−4 °F). These periods usually last about a week or two. The growing season in Moscow normally lasts for 156 days usually around 1 May to 5 October.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}

The highest temperature ever recorded was 38.2 °C (100.8 °F)^[\[67\]](#cite_note-68)^ at the [VVC weather station](/wiki/VVC_weather_station "VVC weather station") and 39.0 °C (102.2 °F) in the center of Moscow and [Domodedovo airport](/wiki/Domodedovo_airport "Domodedovo airport") on 29 July 2010, during the unusual [2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves](/wiki/2010_Northern_Hemisphere_summer_heat_waves "2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves"). Record high and average temperatures were recorded for January, March, April, May, June, July, August, November, and December in 2007--2022.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-pogoda_(data)-69)^ The average July temperature from 1991 to 2020 is 19.7 °C (67.5 °F). The lowest ever recorded temperature was −42.1 °C (−43.8 °F) in January 1940. Snow, which is present for about five months a year, often begins to fall mid-October, while snow cover lies in late November and melts at the end of March.{#cite_ref-pogoda_(data)_69-0}

On average, Moscow has 1731 hours of sunshine per year, varying from a low of 8% in December to 52% from May to August.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-70)^ This large annual variation is due to convective cloud formation. In the winter, moist air from the Atlantic condenses in the cold continental interior, resulting in very overcast conditions. However, this same continental influence results in considerably sunnier summers than oceanic cities of similar latitude such as [Edinburgh](/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh"). Between 2004 and 2010, the average was between 1800 and 2000 hours with a tendency to more sunshine in summer months, up to a record 411 hours in July 2014, 79% of possible sunshine. December 2017 was the darkest month in Moscow since records began, with only six minutes of sunlight.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-71)^^[\[71\]](#cite_note-72)^{#cite_ref-72}

Temperatures in the centre of Moscow are often significantly higher than in the outskirts and nearby suburbs, especially in winter. For example, if the average January temperature in the north-east of Moscow is −6.2 °C (20.8 °F), in the suburbs it is about −8.3 °C (17.1 °F).^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^ The temperature difference between the centre of Moscow and nearby areas of [Moscow Oblast](/wiki/Moscow_Oblast "Moscow Oblast") can sometimes be more than 10 °C (18 °F) on frosty winter nights.{#cite_ref-73}

Recent changes in Moscow's regional climate, since it is in the mid-latitudes of the northern hemisphere, are often cited by climate scientists as evidence of [global warming](/wiki/Global_warming "Global warming"),^[\[82\]](#cite_note-83)^ though by definition, [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change "Climate change") is global, not regional. During the summer, extreme heat is often observed in the city (2001, 2002, 2003, [2010](/wiki/2010_Northern_Hemisphere_summer_heat_wave "2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat wave"), 2011, [2021](/wiki/Heat_waves_of_2021#June "Heat waves of 2021")). Along with a southern part of [Central Russia](/wiki/Central_Federal_District "Central Federal District"),^[\[83\]](#cite_note-84)^^[\[84\]](#cite_note-85)^ after recent years of hot summer seasons, the climate of the city gets [hot-summer classification](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate#Koppen_Dfa "Humid continental climate") trends. Winter also became significantly milder: for example, the average January temperature in the early 1900s was −12.0 °C (10.4 °F), while now it is about −7.0 °C (19.4 °F).^[\[85\]](#cite_note-86)^ At the end of January--February it is often colder, with frosts reaching −30.0 °C (−22.0 °F) a few nights per year (2006, 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013).{#cite_ref-86}

Paleontology {#Paleontology}
----------------------------

Moscow is one of the few cities with paleontological monuments of world significance on its territory.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-Malenkina2017-88)^ One of them is the [Gorodnya River](/w/index.php?title=Gorodnya_River&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gorodnya River (page does not exist)") with its tributaries, on the banks of which outcrops of the [Quaternary](/wiki/Quaternary "Quaternary") and older [Cretaceous](/wiki/Cretaceous "Cretaceous") periods are located. [Fossils](/wiki/Fossil "Fossil") of the [bivalve](/wiki/Bivalve "Bivalve") mollusk *[Inoceramus kleinii](/wiki/Inoceramus "Inoceramus")* and tubular passages of burrowing animals, described in 2017 as a new [ichnospecies](/wiki/Ichnospecies "Ichnospecies") *[Skolithos gorodnensis](/wiki/Skolithos "Skolithos")* , were discovered in the [Coniacian](/wiki/Coniacian "Coniacian") deposits near the stream bed of the Bolshaya Glinka River.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-Malenkina2017-88)^ [Ichnogenera](/wiki/Ichnogenus "Ichnogenus") *[Diplocraterion](/wiki/Diplocraterion "Diplocraterion")* , *[Planolites](/wiki/Planolites "Planolites")* , *Skolithos* and possibly *[Ophiomorpha](/wiki/Ophiomorpha "Ophiomorpha")* were found in the [Albian](/wiki/Albian "Albian") deposits. [Paleolithic](/wiki/Paleolithic "Paleolithic") flint tools were discovered in the Quaternary deposits of the Bolshaya Glinka stream bed.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-Malenkina2017-88)^{#cite_ref-Malenkina2017_88-2}

In 1878, paleontologist [Hermann Trautschold](/wiki/Hermann_Trautschold "Hermann Trautschold") discovered the left flipper of an [ichthyosaur](/wiki/Ichthyosaur "Ichthyosaur") near the village of Mnevniki, which later became part of Moscow. In 2014, the animal was named *[Undorosaurus trautscholdi](/wiki/Undorosaurus "Undorosaurus")* , after its discoverer. Trautschold determined the age of the sediments from which the specimen was taken to be [Kimmeridgian](/wiki/Kimmeridgian "Kimmeridgian"), but, according to more recent studies, they were formed in the [Tithonian](/wiki/Tithonian "Tithonian") age of the [Jurassic](/wiki/Jurassic "Jurassic") period.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Arkhangelsky2014-89)^{#cite_ref-Arkhangelsky2014_89-0}

Albian [foraminifera](/wiki/Foraminifera "Foraminifera") and [ammonites](/wiki/Ammonite "Ammonite") also known from the Moscow deposits.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-Malenkina2017-88)^{#cite_ref-Malenkina2017_88-3}

Fossils of various organisms are on display in Moscow museums, including the [Orlov Museum of Paleontology](/wiki/Moscow_Paleontological_Museum "Moscow Paleontological Museum") and [Vernadsky State Geological Museum](/wiki/Vernadsky_State_Geological_Museum "Vernadsky State Geological Museum").

### Vital statistics {#Vital_statistics}

The official population of Moscow is based on those holding "[permanent residency](/wiki/Resident_registration_in_Russia "Resident registration in Russia")". According to Russia's Federal Migration Service, Moscow holds 1.8 million official "guests" who have temporary residency on the basis of visas or other documentation, giving a legal population of 14.8 million. The number of [Illegal immigrants](/wiki/Illegal_immigration_in_Russia "Illegal immigration in Russia"), the vast majority originating from [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia"), is estimated to be an additional 1 million people,^[\[103\]](#cite_note-105)^ giving a total population of about 15.8 million.{#cite_ref-105}

**Vital statistics for 2022:** ^[\[104\]](#cite_note-106)^^[\[105\]](#cite_note-107)^{#cite_ref-107}

* Births: 123,654 (9.8 per 1,000)
* Deaths: 126,988 (10.1 per 1,000)

**Total fertility rate (2022):** ^[\[106\]](#cite_note-gks.ru-tfr-108)^   

1.42 children per woman{#cite_ref-gks.ru-tfr_108-0}

**Life expectancy (2021):** ^[\[107\]](#cite_note-rosstat-109)^  

Total --- 74.55 years (male --- 71.00, female --- 77.94){#cite_ref-rosstat_109-0}

Clockwise from left: the [Cathedral of Christ the Saviour](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour "Cathedral of Christ the Saviour"), demolished during the Soviet period and reconstructed from 1990--2000; [Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception](/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Immaculate_Conception_(Moscow) "Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception (Moscow)"); [Moscow Cathedral Mosque](/wiki/Moscow_Cathedral_Mosque "Moscow Cathedral Mosque"); and [Moscow Choral Synagogue](/wiki/Moscow_Choral_Synagogue "Moscow Choral Synagogue")

[Christians](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") form the majority of the city's population; most of whom adhere [Russian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church "Russian Orthodox Church"). The [Patriarch of Moscow](/wiki/Patriarch_of_Moscow_and_all_Rus%27 "Patriarch of Moscow and all Rus'") serves as the head of the church and resides in the [Danilov Monastery](/wiki/Danilov_Monastery "Danilov Monastery"). Moscow was called the "city of 40 times 40 churches"---prior to 1917. Moscow is Russia's capital of [Eastern Orthodox Christianity](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"), which has been the [country's traditional religion](/wiki/Religion_in_Russia "Religion in Russia").

Other religions practiced in Moscow include [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Russia "Buddhism in Russia"), [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism_in_Russia "Hinduism in Russia"), [Islam](/wiki/Islam_in_Russia "Islam in Russia"), [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), [Yazidism](/wiki/Yazidism "Yazidism"), and [Rodnovery](/wiki/Rodnovery "Rodnovery"). The Moscow Mufti Council claimed that [Muslims](/wiki/Muslims "Muslims") numbered around 1.5 million of 10.5 million of the city's population in 2010.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-Spie-112)^ There are four [mosques](/wiki/Mosque "Mosque") in the city.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-113)^{#cite_ref-113}

### Architecture {#Architecture}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Museo_Estatal_de_Historia%2C_Mosc%C3%BA%2C_Rusia%2C_2016-10-03%2C_DD_49.jpg/220px-Museo_Estatal_de_Historia%2C_Mosc%C3%BA%2C_Rusia%2C_2016-10-03%2C_DD_49.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museo_Estatal_de_Historia,_Mosc%C3%BA,_Rusia,_2016-10-03,_DD_49.jpg) The [State Historical Museum](/wiki/State_Historical_Museum "State Historical Museum"), an example of the [Neo-Russian style](/wiki/Russian_Revival_architecture "Russian Revival architecture") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Moscow_July_2011-7a.jpg/220px-Moscow_July_2011-7a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_July_2011-7a.jpg) The [Cathedral of Christ the Saviour](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour "Cathedral of Christ the Saviour"), an example of [Neo-Byzantine architecture](/wiki/Neo-Byzantine_architecture_in_the_Russian_Empire "Neo-Byzantine architecture in the Russian Empire")

Moscow's architecture is world-renowned. Moscow is the site of [Saint Basil's Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral "Saint Basil's Cathedral"), with its elegant [onion domes](/wiki/Onion_dome "Onion dome"), as well as the [Cathedral of Christ the Savior](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Savior "Cathedral of Christ the Savior") and the [Seven Sisters](/wiki/Seven_Sisters_(Moscow) "Seven Sisters (Moscow)"). The first Kremlin was built in the middle of the 12th century.

Medieval Moscow's design was of concentric walls and intersecting radial thoroughfares. This layout, as well as Moscow's rivers, helped shape Moscow's design in subsequent centuries.

The Kremlin was rebuilt in the 15th century. Its towers and some of its churches were built by Italian architects, lending the city some of the aurae of the renaissance. From the end of the 15th century, the city was embellished by masonry structures such as monasteries, palaces, walls, towers, and churches.

The city's appearance had not changed much by the 18th century. Houses were made of pine and spruce logs, with shingled roofs plastered with sod or covered by birch bark. The rebuilding of Moscow in the second half of the 18th century was necessitated by constant fires and the needs of the nobility. Much of the wooden city was replaced by buildings in the classical style.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-114)^{#cite_ref-114}

For much of its architectural history, Moscow was dominated by Orthodox churches. However, the overall appearance of the city changed drastically during Soviet times, especially as a result of [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin")'s large-scale effort to "modernize" Moscow. Stalin's plans for the city included a network of broad avenues and roadways, some of them over ten lanes wide, which, while greatly simplifying movement through the city, were constructed at the expense of a great number of historical buildings and districts. Among the many casualties of Stalin's demolitions was the [Sukharev Tower](/wiki/Sukharev_Tower "Sukharev Tower"), a longtime city landmark, as well as mansions and commercial buildings. The city's newfound status as the capital of a deeply [secular](/wiki/Secular "Secular") nation, made religiously significant buildings especially vulnerable to demolition. Many of the city's churches, which in most cases were some of Moscow's oldest and most prominent buildings, were destroyed; some notable examples include the [Kazan Cathedral](/wiki/Kazan_Cathedral,_Moscow "Kazan Cathedral, Moscow") and the Cathedral of Christ the Savior. During the 1990s, both were rebuilt. Many smaller churches, however, were lost.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/0169_-_Moskau_2015_-_Roter_Platz_%2825795529393%29.jpg/220px-0169_-_Moskau_2015_-_Roter_Platz_%2825795529393%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:0169_-_Moskau_2015_-_Roter_Platz_(25795529393).jpg) [GUM](/wiki/GUM_(department_store) "GUM (department store)") department store, facing the [Red Square](/wiki/Red_Square "Red Square") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Ostankino_Tower%2C_2015.JPG/170px-Ostankino_Tower%2C_2015.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ostankino_Tower,_2015.JPG) [Ostankino Tower](/wiki/Ostankino_Tower "Ostankino Tower"), the tallest freestanding structure in Europe, and the [eighth-tallest in the world](/wiki/List_of_tallest_freestanding_structures_in_the_world "List of tallest freestanding structures in the world")

While the later Stalinist period was characterized by the curtailing of creativity and architectural innovation, the earlier post-revolutionary years saw a plethora of radical new buildings created in the city. Especially notable were the constructivist architects associated with [VKHUTEMAS](/wiki/VKHUTEMAS "VKHUTEMAS"), responsible for such landmarks as Lenin's Mausoleum. Another prominent architect was [Vladimir Shukhov](/wiki/Vladimir_Shukhov "Vladimir Shukhov"), famous for Shukhov Tower, just one of many [hyperboloid towers](/wiki/Hyperboloid_structure "Hyperboloid structure") designed by Shukhov. It was built between 1919 and 1922 as a transmission tower for a Russian broadcasting company.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-stako-116)^ Shukhov also left a lasting legacy to the [Constructivist](/wiki/Constructivism_(art) "Constructivism (art)") architecture of early Soviet Russia. He designed spacious elongated shop galleries, most notably the [GUM](/wiki/GUM_(department_store) "GUM (department store)") department store on [Red Square](/wiki/Red_Square "Red Square"),^[\[114\]](#cite_note-stako-116)^ bridged with innovative metal-and-glass vaults.{#cite_ref-stako_116-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Moscow%2C_Hotel_Ukraina_%2830585861673%29.jpg/220px-Moscow%2C_Hotel_Ukraina_%2830585861673%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow,_Hotel_Ukraina_(30585861673).jpg) One of the [Seven Sisters](/wiki/Seven_Sisters_(Moscow) "Seven Sisters (Moscow)"), [Hotel Ukraina](/wiki/Radisson_Royal_Hotel,_Moscow "Radisson Royal Hotel, Moscow"), is the [tallest hotel in Europe](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Europe "List of tallest buildings in Europe"), and one of the [tallest hotels in the world](/wiki/List_of_tallest_hotels "List of tallest hotels"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Zhivopisny_Bridge1.jpg/220px-Zhivopisny_Bridge1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zhivopisny_Bridge1.jpg) [Zhivopisny Bridge](/wiki/Zhivopisny_Bridge "Zhivopisny Bridge"), the highest cable-stayed bridge in Europe

Perhaps the most recognizable contributions of the Stalinist period are the so-called [Seven Sisters](/wiki/Seven_Sisters_(Moscow) "Seven Sisters (Moscow)"), seven massive skyscrapers scattered throughout the city at about an equal distance from the Kremlin. A defining feature of Moscow's skyline, their imposing form was allegedly inspired by the [Manhattan Municipal Building](/wiki/Manhattan_Municipal_Building "Manhattan Municipal Building") in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), and their style---with intricate exteriors and a large central spire---has been described as [Stalinist Gothic architecture](/wiki/Stalinist_architecture "Stalinist architecture"). All seven towers can be seen from most high points in the city; they are among the tallest constructions in central Moscow apart from the [Ostankino Tower](/wiki/Ostankino_Tower "Ostankino Tower"), which, when it was completed in 1967, was the highest free-standing land structure in the world and today remains the world's seventy-second tallest, ranking among buildings such as the [Burj Khalifa](/wiki/Burj_Khalifa "Burj Khalifa") in Dubai, [Taipei 101](/wiki/Taipei_101 "Taipei 101") in Taiwan and the [CN Tower](/wiki/CN_Tower "CN Tower") in Toronto.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

The Soviet goal of providing housing for every family, and the rapid growth of Moscow's population, led to the construction of large, monotonous housing blocks. Most of these date from the post-Stalin era and the styles are often named after the leader then in power (Brezhnev, Khrushchev, etc.). They are usually badly maintained.

Although the city still has some five-story apartment buildings constructed before the mid-1960s, more recent apartment buildings are usually at least nine floors tall, and have [elevators](/wiki/Elevator "Elevator"). It is estimated that Moscow has over twice as many elevators as New York City and four times as many as [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"). Moslift, one of the city's major elevator operating companies, has about 1500 elevator mechanics on call, to release residents trapped in elevators.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

[Stalinist-era buildings](/wiki/Stalinist_architecture "Stalinist architecture"), mostly found in the central part of the city, are massive and usually ornamented with [Socialist realism](/wiki/Socialist_realism "Socialist realism") motifs that imitate [classical](/wiki/Classical_architecture "Classical architecture") themes. However, small churches---almost always [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox")--found across the city provide glimpses of its past. The Old [Arbat Street](/wiki/Arbat_Street "Arbat Street"), a tourist street that was once the heart of a bohemian area, preserves most of its buildings from prior to the 20th century. Many buildings found off the main streets of the inner city (behind the Stalinist [façades](/wiki/Fa%C3%A7ade "Façade") of [Tverskaya Street](/wiki/Tverskaya_Street "Tverskaya Street"), for example) are also examples of [bourgeois](/wiki/Bourgeoisie "Bourgeoisie") architecture typical of Tsarist times. [Ostankino Palace](/wiki/Ostankino_Palace "Ostankino Palace"), [Kuskovo](/wiki/Kuskovo "Kuskovo"), [Uzkoye](/wiki/Uzkoye "Uzkoye") and other large estates just outside Moscow originally belong to nobles from the Tsarist era, and some [convents, and monasteries](/wiki/Template:Cloisters_of_Moscow "Template:Cloisters of Moscow"), both inside and outside the city, are open to Muscovites and tourists.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0%2C_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%8F_%28Unsplash_-kgrPSetNW8%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0%2C_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%8F_%28Unsplash_-kgrPSetNW8%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0,_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%8F_(Unsplash_-kgrPSetNW8).jpg) Modern methods of skyscraper construction were implemented in the city for the first time with the ambitious [MIBC](/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center "Moscow International Business Center").

Attempts are being made to restore many of the city's best-kept examples of pre-Soviet architecture. These restored structures are easily spotted by their bright new colors and spotless façades. There are a few examples of notable, early Soviet [avant-garde](/wiki/Avant-garde "Avant-garde") work too, such as the house of the architect [Konstantin Melnikov](/wiki/Konstantin_Melnikov "Konstantin Melnikov") in the Arbat area. Many of these restorations were criticized for alleged disrespect of historical authenticity. [Facadism](/wiki/Facadism "Facadism") is also widely practiced.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-119)^ Later examples of interesting Soviet architecture are usually marked by their impressive size and the semi-[Modernist](/wiki/Modernist "Modernist") styles employed, such as with the [Novy Arbat](/wiki/Novy_Arbat "Novy Arbat") project, familiarly known as "false teeth of Moscow" and notorious for the wide-scale disruption of a historic area in central Moscow involved in the project.{#cite_ref-119}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Borovitskaya_square1.jpg/220px-Borovitskaya_square1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Borovitskaya_square1.jpg) Borovitskaya square, [Monument to Vladimir the Great](/wiki/Monument_to_Vladimir_the_Great "Monument to Vladimir the Great") and [Pashkov House](/wiki/Pashkov_House "Pashkov House")

Plaques on house exteriors will inform passers-by that a well-known personality once lived there. Frequently, the plaques are dedicated to Soviet celebrities not well known outside (or often, like with decorated generals and revolutionaries, now both inside) of Russia. There are also many "museum houses" of famous Russian writers, composers, and artists in the city.

Moscow's skyline is quickly modernizing, with several new towers under construction. In recent years, the city administration has been widely criticized for heavy destruction that has affected many historical buildings. As much as a third of historic Moscow has been destroyed in the past few years^[\[118\]](#cite_note-120)^ to make space for luxury apartments and hotels.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-121)^ Other historical buildings, including such landmarks as the 1930 Moskva hotel and the 1913 department store Voyentorg, have been razed and reconstructed anew, with the inevitable loss of historical value. Critics blame the government for not enforcing conservation laws: in the last 12 years, more than 50 buildings with monument status were torn down, several of those dating back to the 17th century.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-122)^ Some critics also wonder if the money used for the reconstruction of razed buildings could not be used for the renovation of decaying structures, which include many works by architect Konstantin Melnikov^[\[121\]](#cite_note-123)^ and [Mayakovskaya](/wiki/Mayakovskaya_(Moscow_Metro) "Mayakovskaya (Moscow Metro)") metro station.{#cite_ref-123}

Some organizations, such as Moscow Architecture Preservation Society^[\[122\]](#cite_note-124)^ and Save Europe's Heritage,^[\[123\]](#cite_note-125)^ are trying to draw the international public attention to these problems.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Panorama_360_Red_Square_edit.jpg/1500px-Panorama_360_Red_Square_edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_360_Red_Square_edit.jpg "Red Square is a World Heritage Site.")  
[](/wiki/File:Panorama_360_Red_Square_edit.jpg "File:Panorama 360 Red Square edit.jpg")
[Red Square](/wiki/Red_Square "Red Square") is a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site").

There are 96 parks and 18 gardens in Moscow, including four [botanical gardens](/wiki/Botanical_garden "Botanical garden"). There are 450 square kilometres (170 sq mi) of green zones besides 100 square kilometres (39 sq mi) of forests.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-mosru-stats-127)^ Moscow is a very green city, if compared to other cities of comparable size in Western Europe and North America; this is partly due to a history of having green "yards" with trees and grass, between residential buildings. There are on average 27 square meters (290 sq ft) of parks per person in Moscow compared with 6 for [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), 7.5 in [London](/wiki/London "London") and 8.6 in New York.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-greendress-128)^{#cite_ref-greendress_128-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Moscow_Gorky_Park_main_portal_08-2016_img1.jpg/220px-Moscow_Gorky_Park_main_portal_08-2016_img1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_Gorky_Park_main_portal_08-2016_img1.jpg) [Gorky Park](/wiki/Gorky_Park_(Moscow) "Gorky Park (Moscow)")

[Gorky Park](/wiki/Gorky_Park_(Moscow) "Gorky Park (Moscow)") (officially the [Central Park of Culture and Rest](/wiki/Gorky_Park_(Moscow) "Gorky Park (Moscow)") named after [Maxim Gorky](/wiki/Maxim_Gorky "Maxim Gorky")), was founded in 1928. The main part (689,000 square metres or 170 acres)^[\[126\]](#cite_note-greendress-128)^ along the Moskva river contains [estrades](/wiki/Architectural_glossary#Estrade "Architectural glossary"), children's attractions (including the *Observation Wheel* water ponds with boats and water bicycles), dancing, tennis courts and other sports facilities. It borders the [Neskuchny Garden](/wiki/Neskuchny_Garden "Neskuchny Garden") (408,000 square metres or 101 acres), the oldest park in Moscow and a former imperial residence, created as a result of the integration of three estates in the 18th century. The Garden features the Green Theater, one of the largest open amphitheaters in Europe, able to hold up to 15 thousand people.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-129)^ Several parks include a section known as a "Park of Culture and Rest", sometimes alongside a much wilder area (this includes parks such as Izmaylovsky, Fili and Sokolniki). Some parks are designated as Forest Parks (lesopark).{#cite_ref-129}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Island_of_Dreams2.jpg/220px-Island_of_Dreams2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Island_of_Dreams2.jpg) [Dream Island](/wiki/Dream_Island_(amusement_park) "Dream Island (amusement park)"), the largest indoor theme park in Europe

[Izmaylovsky Park](/wiki/Izmaylovsky_Park "Izmaylovsky Park"), created in 1931, is one of the largest urban parks in the world along with [Richmond Park](/wiki/Richmond_Park "Richmond Park") in London. Its area of 15.34 square kilometres (5.92 sq mi) is six times greater than that of [Central Park](/wiki/Central_Park "Central Park") in New York.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-greendress-128)^{#cite_ref-greendress_128-2}

[Bauman Garden](/wiki/Bauman_Garden_(Moscow) "Bauman Garden (Moscow)"), officially founded in 1920 and renamed in 1922 after the [bolshevik](/wiki/Bolsheviks "Bolsheviks") [Nikolay Bauman](/wiki/Nikolay_Bauman "Nikolay Bauman"), is one of the oldest parks in Moscow. It is standing on the site of the former [Golitsyn](/wiki/House_of_Golitsyn "House of Golitsyn") estate and eighteenth-century public garden.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-130)^{#cite_ref-130}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Novodevichy_Convent_Night.jpg/220px-Novodevichy_Convent_Night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Novodevichy_Convent_Night.jpg) [Novodevichy Convent](/wiki/Novodevichy_Convent "Novodevichy Convent") is a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site").

[Sokolniki Park](/wiki/Sokolniki_Park "Sokolniki Park"), named after the [falcon](/wiki/Falcon "Falcon") hunting that occurred there in the past, is one of the oldest parks in Moscow and has an area of 6 square kilometres (2.3 sq mi). A central circle with a large fountain is surrounded by birch, maple, and elm tree alleys. A labyrinth composed of green paths lies beyond the park's ponds.

[Losiny Ostrov National Park](/wiki/Losiny_Ostrov_National_Park "Losiny Ostrov National Park") ("Elk Island" National Park), with a total area of more than 116 square kilometres (45 sq mi), borders Sokolniki Park and was Russia's first national park. It is quite wild, and is also known as the "city taiga" -- elk can be seen there.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/%D0%A6%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC_%2819.08.2018%29.jpg/170px-%D0%A6%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC_%2819.08.2018%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A6%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC_(19.08.2018).jpg) The Church of Ascension in [Kolomenskoye](/wiki/Kolomenskoye "Kolomenskoye") is a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site").

Tsytsin Main [Botanical Garden of Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Moscow_Botanical_Garden_of_Academy_of_Sciences "Moscow Botanical Garden of Academy of Sciences"), founded in 1945 is the largest in Europe.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-131)^ It covers the territory of 3.61 square kilometres (1.39 sq mi) bordering the All-Russia Exhibition Center and contains a live exhibition of more than 20 thousand species of plants from around the world, as well as a lab for scientific research. It contains a rosarium with 20 thousand rose bushes, a dendrarium, and an oak forest, with the average age of trees exceeding 100 years. There is a greenhouse taking up more than 5,000 square metres (53,820 square feet) of land.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-greendress-128)^{#cite_ref-greendress_128-3}

The All-Russian Exhibition Center (Всероссийский выставочный центр), formerly known as the All-Union Agricultural Exhibition (VSKhV) and later [Exhibition of Achievements of the National Economy](/wiki/VDNKh_(Russia) "VDNKh (Russia)") (VDNKh), though officially named a "permanent trade show", is one of the most prominent examples of Stalinist-era monumental architecture. Among the large spans of a recreational park, areas are scores of elaborate pavilions, each representing either a branch of Soviet industry and science or a USSR republic. Even though during the 1990s it was, and for some part still is, misused as a gigantic shopping center (most of the pavilions are rented out for small businesses), it still retains the bulk of its architectural landmarks, including two monumental fountains (*[Stone Flower](/wiki/The_Stone_Flower_Fountain "The Stone Flower Fountain")* and *Friendship of Nations* ) and a 360 degrees panoramic cinema. In 2014 the park returned to the name Exhibition of Achievements of National Economy, and in the same year, huge renovation works had been started.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}

*Lilac Park* , founded in 1958, has a permanent sculpture display and a large rosarium. Moscow has always been a popular destination for tourists. Some of the more famous attractions include the city's UNESCO World Heritage Site, Moscow Kremlin and Red Square,^[\[131\]](#cite_note-133)^ which was built between the 14th and 17th centuries.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-134)^ The [Church of the Ascension](/wiki/Kolomenskoye#The_White_Column_of_Kolomenskoye "Kolomenskoye") at Kolomenskoye, which dates from 1532, is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site and another popular attraction.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-135)^{#cite_ref-135}

Near the [new Tretyakov Gallery](/wiki/Tretyakov_Gallery "Tretyakov Gallery") there is a sculpture garden, Museon, often called "[the graveyard of fallen monuments](/wiki/The_graveyard_of_fallen_monuments "The graveyard of fallen monuments")" that displays statues of the former Soviet Union that were removed from their place after its dissolution.

Other attractions include the [Moscow Zoo](/wiki/Moscow_Zoo "Moscow Zoo"), a zoological garden in two sections (the valleys of two streams) linked by a bridge, with nearly a thousand species and more than 6,500 specimens.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-moszoo-136)^ Each year, the zoo attracts more than 1.2 million visitors.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-moszoo-136)^ Many of Moscow's parks and landscaped gardens are protected natural environments.{#cite_ref-moszoo_136-1}
