Moscow rings {#Moscow_rings}
----------------------------

Moscow's road system is centered roughly on the Kremlin at the heart of the city. From there, roads generally span outwards to intersect with a sequence of circular roads ("rings").

1. The first and innermost major ring, Bulvarnoye Koltso ([Boulevard Ring](/wiki/Boulevard_Ring "Boulevard Ring")), was built at the former location of the 16th-century city wall around what used to be called [Bely Gorod](/wiki/Bely_Gorod "Bely Gorod") (White Town).^[\[135\]](#cite_note-golden-ring-137)^ The Bulvarnoye Koltso is technically not a ring; it does not form a complete circle, but instead a [horseshoe-shaped](/wiki/Horseshoe-shaped "Horseshoe-shaped") arc that begins at the Cathedral of Christ the Savior and ends at the [Yauza River](/wiki/Yauza_River "Yauza River").{#cite_ref-golden-ring_137-0}
2. The second primary ring, located outside the Boulevard Ring, is the Sadovoye Koltso ([Garden Ring](/wiki/Garden_Ring "Garden Ring")). Like the Boulevard Ring, the Garden Ring follows the path of a 16th-century wall that used to encompass part of Moscow.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-golden-ring-137)^ [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/ISS-38_Nighttime_image_of_Moscow%2C_Russia.jpg/290px-ISS-38_Nighttime_image_of_Moscow%2C_Russia.jpg)](/wiki/File:ISS-38_Nighttime_image_of_Moscow,_Russia.jpg) Moscow as viewed from the [International Space Station](/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station"), 29 January 2014 {#cite_ref-golden-ring_137-1}
3. The [Third Ring Road](/wiki/Third_Ring_Road_(Moscow) "Third Ring Road (Moscow)"), was completed in 2003 as a high-speed [freeway](/wiki/Freeway "Freeway").
4. The Fourth Transport Ring, another freeway, was planned, but cancelled in 2011. A system of chordal highways will replace it.

Aside from the aforementioned hierarchy, line 5 of [Moscow Metro](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro") is a circle-shaped [looped](/wiki/Loop_line_(railway) "Loop line (railway)") subway line (hence the name *Koltsevaya Liniya* , literally "ring line"), which is located between the *Sadovoye Koltso* and Third Transport Ring.

Two modern overlapping lines of Moscow Metro form "two hearts":

* Line 14. Since 10 September 2016, *[Moscow Central Circle](/wiki/Moscow_Central_Circle "Moscow Central Circle")* renovated railroad (former *Moskovskaya Okruzhnaya Zheleznaya Doroga* ) was introduced as Line 14 of [Moscow Metro](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro"). The cone-shaped railroad initially opened in 1908 (freight-only railway from 1934 until the 2016 reopening).
* Line 11. Another circle metro line - *Big Circle Line* (*[Bolshaya Koltsevaya Liniya](/wiki/Bolshaya_Koltsevaya_line "Bolshaya Koltsevaya line")* ) is under construction and will be finished in 2023. [Kakhovskaya](/wiki/Kakhovskaya_(Moscow_Metro) "Kakhovskaya (Moscow Metro)")-[Savyolovskaya](/wiki/Savyolovskaya_(Bolshaya_Koltsevaya_line) "Savyolovskaya (Bolshaya Koltsevaya line)") western half of the line was launched in late 2021.

The outermost ring within Moscow is the [Moscow Ring Road](/wiki/Moscow_Ring_Road "Moscow Ring Road") (often called *MKAD* , acronym word for Russian *Московская Кольцевая Автомобильная Дорога*), which forms the cultural boundary of the city, and was established in the 1950s. It is to note the method of building the road (usage of ground elevation instead of concrete columns throughout the whole way) formed a wall-like barrier that obstacles building roads under the MKAD highway itself).

* Before 2012 expansion of Moscow, MKAD was considered an approximate border for Moscow boundaries.

Outside Moscow, some of the roads encompassing the city continue to follow this circular pattern seen inside city limits, with the notable examples of *Betonka* roads (highways A107 and A108), originally made of concrete pads.

In order to reduce transit traffic on MKAD, the new ring road (called *CKAD* - *Centralnaya Koltsevaya Avtomobilnaya Doroga* , *Central Ring Road*) is now under construction beyond the MKAD.

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

### Museums and galleries {#Museums_and_galleries}

One of the most notable art museums in Moscow is the [Tretyakov Gallery](/wiki/Tretyakov_Gallery "Tretyakov Gallery"), which was founded by [Pavel Tretyakov](/wiki/Pavel_Tretyakov "Pavel Tretyakov"), a wealthy patron of the arts who donated a large private collection to the city.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-138)^ The Tretyakov Gallery is split into two buildings. The Old Tretyakov gallery, the original gallery in the [Tretyakovskaya](/wiki/Tretyakov_Gallery "Tretyakov Gallery") area on the south bank of the Moskva River, houses works in the classic Russian tradition.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-trety-139)^ The works of famous pre-[Revolutionary](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution") painters, such as [Ilya Repin](/wiki/Ilya_Repin "Ilya Repin"), as well as the works of early Russian [icon painters](/wiki/Icon_painting "Icon painting") can be found here. Visitors can even see rare originals by early 15th-century [iconographer](/wiki/Iconography "Iconography") [Andrei Rublev](/wiki/Andrei_Rublev "Andrei Rublev").^[\[137\]](#cite_note-trety-139)^ The New Tretyakov gallery, created in Soviet times, mainly contains the works of Soviet artists, as well as of a few contemporary paintings, but there is some overlap with the Old Tretyakov Gallery for early 20th-century art. The new gallery includes a small reconstruction of [Vladimir Tatlin](/wiki/Vladimir_Tatlin "Vladimir Tatlin")'s famous *[Monument to the Third International](/wiki/Tatlin%27s_Tower "Tatlin's Tower")* and a mixture of other avant-garde works by artists like [Kazimir Malevich](/wiki/Kazimir_Malevich "Kazimir Malevich") and [Wassily Kandinsky](/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky "Wassily Kandinsky"). Socialist realism features can also be found within the halls of the New Tretyakov Gallery.{#cite_ref-trety_139-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Gmii.jpg/220px-Gmii.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gmii.jpg) The [Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts](/wiki/Pushkin_Museum "Pushkin Museum")

Another art museum in the city of Moscow is the [Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts](/wiki/Pushkin_Museum "Pushkin Museum"), which was founded by, among others, the father of [Marina Tsvetaeva](/wiki/Marina_Tsvetaeva "Marina Tsvetaeva"). The Pushkin Museum is similar to the [British Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum") in London in that its halls are a cross-section of exhibits on world civilisations, with many copies of ancient sculptures. However, it also hosts paintings from every major Western era; works by [Claude Monet](/wiki/Claude_Monet "Claude Monet"), [Paul Cézanne](/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne "Paul Cézanne"), and [Pablo Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso") are present in the museum's collection.

The [State Historical Museum](/wiki/State_Historical_Museum "State Historical Museum") of Russia (Государственный Исторический музей) is a museum of Russian history located between Red Square and [Manege Square](/wiki/Manezhnaya_Square,_Moscow "Manezhnaya Square, Moscow") in Moscow. Its exhibitions range from relics of the prehistoric tribes inhabiting present-day Russia, through priceless artworks acquired by members of the Romanov dynasty. The total number of objects in the museum's collection numbers is several million. The [Polytechnical Museum](/wiki/Polytechnical_Museum "Polytechnical Museum"),^[\[138\]](#cite_note-140)^ founded in 1872 is the largest technical museum in Russia, offering a wide array of historical inventions and technological achievements, including humanoid automata from the 18th century and the first Soviet computers. Its collection contains more than 160,000 items.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-141)^ The Borodino Panorama^[\[140\]](#cite_note-142)^ museum located on Kutuzov Avenue provides an opportunity for visitors to experience being on a battlefield with a 360° [diorama](/wiki/Diorama "Diorama"). It is a part of the large historical memorial commemorating the victory in the Patriotic War of 1812 over Napoleon's army, that includes also the [triumphal arch](/wiki/Triumphal_Arch_of_Moscow "Triumphal Arch of Moscow"), erected in 1827. There is also a military history museum that includes statues, and military hardware. [Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics](/wiki/Memorial_Museum_of_Cosmonautics "Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics") under the [Monument to the Conquerors of Space](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Conquerors_of_Space "Monument to the Conquerors of Space") at the end of [Cosmonauts Alley](/wiki/Cosmonauts_Alley "Cosmonauts Alley") is the central memorial place for the Russian space officials.{#cite_ref-142}

The [Shchusev State Museum of Architecture](/wiki/Shchusev_State_Museum_of_Architecture "Shchusev State Museum of Architecture") is the national museum of Russian architecture by the name of the architect [Alexey Shchusev](/wiki/Alexey_Shchusev "Alexey Shchusev") near the Kremlin area.

Moscow will get its own branch of the Hermitage Museum in 2024, with authorities having agreed upon the final project, to be executed by Hani Rashid, co-founder of New York-based 'Asymptote Architecture' - the same bureau that is behind the city's stock market building, the Busan-based World Business Center Solomon Tower and the Strata Tower in Abu-Dhabi.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}

### Performing arts {#Performing_arts}

Moscow is the heart of the Russian performing arts, including [ballet](/wiki/Russian_ballet "Russian ballet") and film, with 68 museums^[\[142\]](#cite_note-144)^ 103^[\[143\]](#cite_note-145)^ theaters, 132 cinemas and 24 concert halls. Among Moscow's theaters and ballet studios is the [Bolshoi Theatre](/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre "Bolshoi Theatre") and the Malyi Theatre^[\[144\]](#cite_note-146)^ as well as [Vakhtangov Theatre](/wiki/Vakhtangov_Theatre "Vakhtangov Theatre") and [Moscow Art Theatre](/wiki/Moscow_Art_Theatre "Moscow Art Theatre").{#cite_ref-146}

The Moscow International Performance Arts Center,^[\[145\]](#cite_note-147)^ opened in 2003, also known as [Moscow International House of Music](/wiki/Moscow_International_House_of_Music "Moscow International House of Music"), is known for its performances in classical music. It has the largest [organ](/wiki/Organ_(music) "Organ (music)") in Russia installed in Svetlanov Hall.{#cite_ref-147}

There are also two large circuses in Moscow: [Moscow State Circus](/wiki/Moscow_State_Circus "Moscow State Circus") and [Moscow Circus on Tsvetnoy Boulevard](/wiki/Moscow_Circus_on_Tsvetnoy_Boulevard "Moscow Circus on Tsvetnoy Boulevard")^[\[146\]](#cite_note-148)^ named after [Yuri Nikulin](/wiki/Yuri_Nikulin "Yuri Nikulin").{#cite_ref-148}

The [Mosfilm](/wiki/Mosfilm "Mosfilm") studio was at the heart of many classic films, as it is responsible for both artistic and mainstream productions.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-149)^ However, despite the continued presence and reputation of internationally renowned Russian filmmakers, the once prolific native studios are much quieter. Rare and historical films may be seen in the Salut cinema, where films from the Museum of Cinema^[\[148\]](#cite_note-150)^ collection are shown regularly. International film festivals such as the [Moscow International Film Festival](/wiki/Moscow_International_Film_Festival "Moscow International Film Festival"), [Stalker](/wiki/Stalker_(film_festival) "Stalker (film festival)"), [Artdocfest](/wiki/Artdocfest "Artdocfest"), and [Moscow Jewish Film Festival](/wiki/Moscow_Jewish_Film_Festival "Moscow Jewish Film Festival") are staged in Moscow.{#cite_ref-150}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/LuzhnikiStadium.jpg/220px-LuzhnikiStadium.jpg)](/wiki/File:LuzhnikiStadium.jpg) The [Luzhniki Stadium](/wiki/Luzhniki_Stadium "Luzhniki Stadium") hosted the [1980 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics") and the [2018 FIFA World Cup Final](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2018 FIFA World Cup Final"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Sparrow_Hills_fanzone_2018.jpg/220px-Sparrow_Hills_fanzone_2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sparrow_Hills_fanzone_2018.jpg) [Sparrow Hills](/wiki/Sparrow_Hills "Sparrow Hills") fanzone during [2018 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Moscow_05-2017_img48_Olimpiysky_Arena.jpg/220px-Moscow_05-2017_img48_Olimpiysky_Arena.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_05-2017_img48_Olimpiysky_Arena.jpg) [SC Olimpiyskiy](/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Moscow) "Olympic Stadium (Moscow)") was built for the [1980 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics").

Over 500 Olympic sports champions lived in the city by 2005.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-151)^ Moscow is home to 63 stadiums (besides eight football and eleven light athletics maneges), of which [Luzhniki Stadium](/wiki/Luzhniki_Stadium "Luzhniki Stadium") is the largest and the 4th biggest in Europe (it hosted the [1998--99 UEFA Cup](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_UEFA_Cup "1998–99 UEFA Cup"), [2007--08 UEFA Champions League](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_UEFA_Champions_League "2007–08 UEFA Champions League") finals, the [1980 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics"), and the [2018 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") with 7 games total, including the [final](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2018 FIFA World Cup Final")). Forty other sports complexes are located within the city, including 24 with artificial ice. The [Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Moscow_arena) "Olympic Stadium (Moscow arena)") was the world's first indoor arena for [bandy](/wiki/Bandy "Bandy") and hosted the [Bandy World Championship](/wiki/Bandy_World_Championship "Bandy World Championship") twice.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-152)^ Moscow was again the host of the competition in 2010, this time in [Krylatskoye](/wiki/Ice_Palace_Krylatskoye "Ice Palace Krylatskoye").^[\[151\]](#cite_note-153)^ That arena has also hosted the [World Speed Skating Championships](/wiki/World_Speed_Skating_Championships "World Speed Skating Championships"). There are also seven [horse racing](/wiki/Horse_racing "Horse racing") tracks in Moscow,^[\[125\]](#cite_note-mosru-stats-127)^ of which [Central Moscow Hippodrome](/wiki/Central_Moscow_Hippodrome "Central Moscow Hippodrome"),^[\[152\]](#cite_note-154)^ founded in 1834, is the largest.{#cite_ref-154}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/CSKA_Arena_%28Quintin_Soloviev%29.jpg/220px-CSKA_Arena_%28Quintin_Soloviev%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:CSKA_Arena_(Quintin_Soloviev).jpg) [CSKA Arena](/wiki/CSKA_Arena "CSKA Arena") during a game of [KHL](/wiki/Kontinental_Hockey_League "Kontinental Hockey League"), considered to be the second-best ice hockey league in the world

Moscow was the host city of the [1980 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics"), with the [yachting](/wiki/Yachting "Yachting") events being held at [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn"), in present-day [Estonia](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia"). Large sports facilities and the main international airport, Sheremetyevo Terminal 2, were built in preparation for the 1980 Summer Olympics. Moscow had made a bid for the [2012 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics"). However, when final voting commenced on 6 July 2005, Moscow was the first city to be eliminated from further rounds. The Games were awarded to [London](/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics").

The most titled [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") team in the Soviet Union and in the world, [HC CSKA Moscow](/wiki/HC_CSKA_Moscow "HC CSKA Moscow") comes from Moscow. Other big ice hockey clubs from Moscow are [HC Dynamo Moscow](/wiki/HC_Dynamo_Moscow "HC Dynamo Moscow"), which was the second most titled team in the Soviet Union, and [HC Spartak Moscow](/wiki/HC_Spartak_Moscow "HC Spartak Moscow").

The most titled Soviet, Russian, and one of the most titled [Euroleague](/wiki/Euroleague "Euroleague") clubs, is the [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") club from Moscow [PBC CSKA Moscow](/wiki/PBC_CSKA_Moscow "PBC CSKA Moscow"). Moscow hosted the [EuroBasket](/wiki/EuroBasket "EuroBasket") in 1953 and 1965.

Moscow had more winners at the [USSR](/wiki/USSR_Chess_Championship "USSR Chess Championship") and [Russian Chess Championship](/wiki/Russian_Chess_Championship "Russian Chess Championship") than any other city.

The most titled [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball") team in the Soviet Union and in Europe ([CEV Champions League](/wiki/CEV_Champions_League "CEV Champions League")) is [VC CSKA Moscow](/wiki/VC_CSKA_Moscow "VC CSKA Moscow").

In [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football"), [FC Spartak Moscow](/wiki/FC_Spartak_Moscow "FC Spartak Moscow") has won more championship titles in the [Russian Premier League](/wiki/Russian_Premier_League "Russian Premier League") than any other team. They were second only to [FC Dynamo Kyiv](/wiki/FC_Dynamo_Kyiv "FC Dynamo Kyiv") in [Soviet times](/wiki/Soviet_Top_League "Soviet Top League"). [PFC CSKA Moscow](/wiki/PFC_CSKA_Moscow "PFC CSKA Moscow") became the first Russian football team to win a [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") title, the [UEFA Cup](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_UEFA_Cup "2004–05 UEFA Cup") (present-day [UEFA Europa League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League")). [FC Lokomotiv Moscow](/wiki/FC_Lokomotiv_Moscow "FC Lokomotiv Moscow"), [FC Dynamo Moscow](/wiki/FC_Dynamo_Moscow "FC Dynamo Moscow") and [FC Torpedo Moscow](/wiki/FC_Torpedo_Moscow "FC Torpedo Moscow") are other professional football teams also based in Moscow.

Moscow houses other prominent football, ice hockey, and basketball teams. Because sports organisations in the Soviet Union were once highly centralized, two of the best Union-level teams represented defence and law-enforcing agencies: the Armed Forces ([CSKA](/wiki/CSKA_Moscow "CSKA Moscow")) and the Ministry of Internal Affairs ([Dinamo](/wiki/Dynamo_Sports_Club "Dynamo Sports Club")). There were army and police teams in most major cities. As a result, Spartak, CSKA, and Dinamo were among the best-funded teams in the USSR.

The [Irina Viner-Usmanova Gymnastics Palace](/wiki/Irina_Viner-Usmanova_Gymnastics_Palace "Irina Viner-Usmanova Gymnastics Palace") is located in the [Luzniki Olympic Complex](/wiki/Luzhniki_Olympic_Complex "Luzhniki Olympic Complex"). The building works started in 2017 and the opening ceremony took place on 18 June 2019. The investor of the Palace is the billionaire [Alisher Usmanov](/wiki/Alisher_Usmanov "Alisher Usmanov"), husband of the former gymnast and gymnastics coach [Irina Viner-Usmanova](/wiki/Irina_Viner-Usmanova "Irina Viner-Usmanova"). The total surface of the building is 23,500 m^2^, which include 3 fitness rooms, locker rooms, rooms reserved for referees and coaches, saunas, a canteen, a cafeteria, 2 ball halls, a Medical center, a hall reserved for journalists, and a hotel for athletes.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-155)^{#cite_ref-155}

Because of Moscow's cold local climate, [winter sports](/wiki/Winter_sport "Winter sport") have a following. Many of Moscow's large parks offer marked trails for skiing and frozen ponds for skating.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/2018_World_Cup_Final_-_France_v_Croatia_-_1st_Half.jpg/220px-2018_World_Cup_Final_-_France_v_Croatia_-_1st_Half.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018_World_Cup_Final_-_France_v_Croatia_-_1st_Half.jpg) The [Luzhniki Stadium](/wiki/Luzhniki_Stadium "Luzhniki Stadium") in Moscow, which hosted games of the [2018 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup")

Moscow hosts the annual [Kremlin Cup](/wiki/Kremlin_Cup "Kremlin Cup"), a popular tennis tournament on both the [WTA](/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association "Women's Tennis Association") and [ATP](/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals "Association of Tennis Professionals") tours. It is one of the ten Tier-I events on the women's tour and a host of Russian players feature every year.

[SC Olimpiyskiy](/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Moscow) "Olympic Stadium (Moscow)") hosted the [Eurovision Song Contest 2009](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2009 "Eurovision Song Contest 2009"), the first and so far the only [Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest "Eurovision Song Contest") arranged in Russia.

[Slava Moscow](/wiki/Slava_Moscow "Slava Moscow") is a professional [rugby](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") club, competing in the national [Professional Rugby League](/wiki/Professional_Rugby_League "Professional Rugby League"). Former [rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") heavyweights [RC Lokomotiv](/wiki/RC_Lokomotiv_Moscow "RC Lokomotiv Moscow") have entered the same league as of 2011^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Moscow&action=edit)^. The Luzhniki Stadium also hosted the [2013 Rugby World Cup Sevens](/wiki/2013_Rugby_World_Cup_Sevens "2013 Rugby World Cup Sevens").

In bandy, one of the most successful clubs in the world is 20 times [Russian League](/wiki/Russian_Bandy_Super_League "Russian Bandy Super League") champions [Dynamo Moscow](/wiki/Dynamo_Moscow_Bandy_Club "Dynamo Moscow Bandy Club"). They have also won the [World Cup](/wiki/Bandy_World_Cup "Bandy World Cup") thrice and [European Cup](/wiki/European_Cup_(bandy) "European Cup (bandy)") six times.

[MFK Dinamo Moskva](/wiki/MFK_Dinamo_Moskva "MFK Dinamo Moskva") is one of the major [futsal](/wiki/Futsal "Futsal") clubs in Europe, having won the [Futsal Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Futsal_Champions_League "UEFA Futsal Champions League") title once.

When Russia was selected to host the [2018 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup"), the Luzhniki Stadium got an increased capacity, by almost 10,000 new seats, in addition to a further two stadiums that have been built: the [Dynamo Stadium](/wiki/VTB_Arena "VTB Arena"), and the [Spartak Stadium](/wiki/Lukoil_Arena "Lukoil Arena"), although the first one later was dismissed from having World Cup matches.

Entertainment {#Entertainment}
------------------------------

See also: [List of shopping malls in Moscow](/wiki/List_of_shopping_malls_in_Moscow "List of shopping malls in Moscow")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Arbat_Street_in_MSK.jpg/220px-Arbat_Street_in_MSK.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arbat_Street_in_MSK.jpg) [Arbat Street](/wiki/Arbat_Street "Arbat Street"), in the historical centre of Moscow

The city is full of clubs, restaurants, and bars. [Tverskaya Street](/wiki/Tverskaya_Street "Tverskaya Street") is also one of the busiest shopping streets in Moscow.

The adjoining [Tretyakovsky Proyezd](/wiki/Tretyakovsky_Proyezd "Tretyakovsky Proyezd"), also south of Tverskaya Street, in [Kitai-gorod](/wiki/Kitai-gorod "Kitai-gorod"), is host to upmarket boutique stores such as [Bulgari](/wiki/Bulgari "Bulgari"), [Tiffany \& Co.](/wiki/Tiffany_%26_Co. "Tiffany & Co."), [Armani](/wiki/Armani "Armani"), [Prada](/wiki/Prada "Prada") and [Bentley](/wiki/Bentley "Bentley").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-go-mag-156)^ [Nightlife](/wiki/Nightlife "Nightlife") in Moscow has moved on since Soviet times and today the city has many of the world's largest [nightclubs](/wiki/Nightclubs "Nightclubs").^[\[155\]](#cite_note-157)^ The hottest area is located around the old chocolate factory, where bars, nightclubs, galleries, cafés and restaurants are placed.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

[Dream Island](/wiki/Dream_Island_(amusement_park) "Dream Island (amusement park)") is an amusement park in Moscow that opened on 29 February 2020.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-159)^^[\[158\]](#cite_note-160)^ It is the largest indoor theme park in Europe. The park covers 300,000 square meters. The complex includes a landscaped park along with a concert hall, a cinema, a hotel, a children's sailing school, restaurants, and shops.{#cite_ref-160}  

Authorities {#Authorities}
--------------------------

### Moscow authorities {#Moscow_authorities}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Tverskaya13_Moscow_06-2015.jpg/220px-Tverskaya13_Moscow_06-2015.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tverskaya13_Moscow_06-2015.jpg) [Government of Moscow](/wiki/Government_of_Moscow "Government of Moscow")

According to the [Constitution of the Russian Federation](/wiki/Constitution_of_Russia "Constitution of Russia"), Moscow is an independent [federal subject](/wiki/Federal_subject "Federal subject") of the [Russian Federation](/wiki/Russia "Russia"), a [city of federal importance](/wiki/Federal_cities_of_Russia "Federal cities of Russia").

The [Mayor of Moscow](/wiki/Mayor_of_Moscow "Mayor of Moscow") is the leading official in the executive, leading the [Government of Moscow](/wiki/Government_of_Moscow "Government of Moscow"), which is the highest organ of executive power. The [Moscow City Duma](/wiki/Moscow_City_Duma "Moscow City Duma") is the [city duma](/wiki/City_duma "City duma") ([city council](/wiki/City_council "City council") or local [parliament](/wiki/Parliament "Parliament")) and local laws must be approved by it. It includes 45 members who are elected for a five-year term on [single-mandate constituency](/wiki/Electoral_district "Electoral district") basis.

From 2006 to 2012, direct elections of the mayor were not held due to changes in the [Charter of the city of Moscow](/wiki/Charter_of_the_city_of_Moscow "Charter of the city of Moscow"), with the mayor appointed by presidential decree. The first direct elections from the time of the [2003 vote](/wiki/2003_Moscow_mayoral_election "2003 Moscow mayoral election") were to be held after the expiration of the current mayor in 2015, however, in connection with his resignation of his own free will, they took place in [September 2013](/wiki/2013_Moscow_mayoral_election "2013 Moscow mayoral election").

Local administration is carried out through eleven prefectures, uniting the districts of Moscow into administrative districts on a territorial basis, and 125 regional administrations. According to the law "On the organization of local self-government in the city of Moscow", since the beginning of 2003, the executive bodies of local self-government are municipalities, representative bodies are municipal assemblies, whose members are elected in accordance with the Charter of the intracity municipality.  

### Federal authorities {#Federal_authorities}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%A4.jpg/220px-%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%A4.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%A4.jpg) [The House of the Government of the Russian Federation](/wiki/White_House_(Moscow) "White House (Moscow)")

In Moscow, as in a city endowed with the [Constitution of the Russian Federation](/wiki/Constitution_of_Russia "Constitution of Russia"), the legislative, executive, and judicial federal authorities of the country are located, with the exception of the [Constitutional Court of the Russian Federation](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Russia "Constitutional Court of Russia"), which has been located in [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg") since 2008.

The supreme executive authority -- the [Government of the Russian Federation](/wiki/Government_of_Russia "Government of Russia") -- is located in the House of the Government of the Russian Federation (the [White House](/wiki/White_House_(Moscow) "White House (Moscow)")) on [Krasnopresnenskaya Embankment](/wiki/Krasnopresnenskaya_Embankment "Krasnopresnenskaya Embankment") in the center of Moscow. The [State Duma](/wiki/State_Duma "State Duma") sits on [Okhotny Ryad](/wiki/Okhotny_Ryad_(street) "Okhotny Ryad (street)"). The [Federation Council](/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia) "Federation Council (Russia)") is located in a building on [Bolshaya Dmitrovka](/wiki/Bolshaya_Dmitrovka_Street "Bolshaya Dmitrovka Street"). The [Supreme Court of the Russian Federation](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Russia "Supreme Court of Russia") is also located in Moscow.

The [Moscow Kremlin](/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin "Moscow Kremlin") is the official residence of the President of the Russian Federation. The president's working residence in the Kremlin is located in the [Senate Palace](/wiki/Kremlin_Senate "Kremlin Senate").  

### Safety {#Safety}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Police_bmw.jpg/220px-Police_bmw.jpg)](/wiki/File:Police_bmw.jpg) A [BMW 5 Series](/wiki/BMW_5_Series "BMW 5 Series") of the [Moscow Police](/wiki/Moscow_City_Police "Moscow City Police") on patrol

In a ranking of the safest cities by *[The Economist](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit")* in 2021, Moscow occupied the 38th position with a score of 62.5 points.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-161)^ The general level of crime is quite low.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-162)^ More than 170,000 surveillance cameras in Moscow are connected to the facial recognition system. The authorities recognized the successful two-month experiment with automatic recognition of faces, gender, and age of people in real-time -- and deployed the system to the whole city. The network of video surveillance unites access video cameras (95% of residential apartment buildings in the capital), cameras in the territory and in buildings of schools and kindergartens, at the [MCC](/wiki/Moscow_Central_Circle "Moscow Central Circle") stations, stadiums, public transport stops, and bus stations, in parks, underground passages.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-163)^{#cite_ref-163}

The emergency numbers are the same as in all the other regions of Russia: 112 is the Single Emergency Number, 101 is the number of the Fire Service and [Ministry of Emergency Situations](/wiki/Ministry_of_Emergency_Situations_(Russia) "Ministry of Emergency Situations (Russia)"), 102 is the [Police](/wiki/Police_of_Russia "Police of Russia") one, 103 is the ambulance one, 104 is the Emergency Gas number.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-164)^ Moscow's EMS is the second most efficient one among the world's megacities, as reported by PwC during the presentation of the international study Analysis of EMS Efficiency in Megacities of the World.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-165)^{#cite_ref-165}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Moscow_territory_1922_1995.gif/220px-Moscow_territory_1922_1995.gif)](/wiki/File:Moscow_territory_1922_1995.gif) Territorial change of Moscow from 1922 to 1995

The entire city of Moscow is headed by one mayor ([Sergey Sobyanin](/wiki/Sergey_Sobyanin "Sergey Sobyanin")). The city of Moscow is divided into twelve administrative okrugs and 125 districts.

The Russian capital's town-planning development began to show as early as the 12th century when the city was founded. The central part of Moscow grew by consolidating with suburbs in line with medieval principles of urban development when strong fortress walls would gradually spread along the circle streets of adjacent new settlements. The first circular defence walls set the trajectory of Moscow's rings, laying the groundwork for the future planning of the Russian capital.

The following fortifications served as the city's circular defense boundaries at some point in history: the Kremlin walls, Zemlyanoy Gorod (Earthwork Town), the Kamer-Kollezhsky Rampart, the Garden Ring, and the small railway ring. The Moscow Ring Road (MKAD) has been Moscow's boundary since 1960. Also in the form of a circle are the main Moscow subway line, the Ring Line, and the so-called Third Automobile Ring, which was completed in 2005. Hence, the characteristic radial-circle planning continues to define Moscow's further development. However, contemporary Moscow has also engulfed a number of territories outside the MKAD, such as Solntsevo, Butovo, and the town of [Zelenograd](/wiki/Zelenograd "Zelenograd"). A part of [Moscow Oblast](/wiki/Moscow_Oblast "Moscow Oblast")'s territory was merged into Moscow on 1 July 2012; as a result, Moscow is no longer fully surrounded by Moscow Oblast and now also has a border with [Kaluga Oblast](/wiki/Kaluga_Oblast "Kaluga Oblast").^[\[164\]](#cite_note-Merger-166)^ In all, Moscow gained about 1,500 square kilometers (580 sq mi) and 230,000 inhabitants. Moscow's Mayor Sergey Sobyanin lauded the expansion that will help Moscow and the neighboring region, a "mega-city" of twenty million people, to develop "harmonically".^[\[61\]](#cite_note-Merger2-62)^{#cite_ref-Merger2_62-1}

All administrative okrugs and districts have their own [coats of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms "Coat of arms") and flags as well as individual heads of the area.

In addition to the districts, there are Territorial Units with Special Status. These usually include areas with small or no permanent populations. Such is the case with the All-Russia Exhibition Centre, the [Botanical Garden](/wiki/Moscow_Botanical_Garden_of_Academy_of_Sciences "Moscow Botanical Garden of Academy of Sciences"), large parks, and industrial zones. In recent years, some territories have been merged with different districts. There are no ethnic-specific regions in Moscow, as in the [Chinatowns](/wiki/Chinatown "Chinatown") that exist in some [North American](/wiki/North_America "North America") and [East Asian](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia") cities. And although districts are not designated by income, as with most cities, those areas that are closer to the city center, metro stations or green zones are considered more prestigious.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-167)^{#cite_ref-167}

Moscow also hosts some of the government bodies of [Moscow Oblast](/wiki/Moscow_Oblast "Moscow Oblast"), although the city itself is not a part of the oblast.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-MoscowO-168)^{#cite_ref-MoscowO_168-0}
