Moscow has one of the [largest municipal economies in Europe](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP") and it accounts more than one-fifth of Russia's [gross domestic product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") (GDP).^[\[168\]](#cite_note-170)^ As of 2021^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Moscow&action=edit)^, the [GRP](/wiki/Gross_Regional_Product "Gross Regional Product") of Moscow reached almost ₽24.5 trillion([US$](/wiki/US$ "US$")332 billion).^[\[169\]](#cite_note-171)^ GMP of Moscow Region was ₽31.3 trillion or around US$425 billion.{#cite_ref-171}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Moscow_Exhacnge_main_building.jpg/170px-Moscow_Exhacnge_main_building.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_Exhacnge_main_building.jpg) [Moscow Exchange](/wiki/Moscow_Exchange "Moscow Exchange")

The average gross monthly wage in the city is ₽123,688^[\[170\]](#cite_note-172)^ ([US$](/wiki/US$ "US$")2,000), which is around twice the national average of ₽66,572 ([US$](/wiki/US$ "US$")1,000), and one of the highest among the federal subjects of Russia.{#cite_ref-172}

Moscow is home to the [third-highest number of billionaires](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_number_of_billionaires "List of cities by number of billionaires") of any city in the world,^[\[171\]](#cite_note-173)^ and has the highest number of billionaires of any city in Europe. It is the financial center of Russia and home to the country's largest banks and many of its largest companies, such as oil giant [Rosneft](/wiki/Rosneft "Rosneft"). Moscow accounts for 17% of retail sales in Russia and for 13% of all construction activity in the country.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-bofit_42_2010-174)^^[\[173\]](#cite_note-175)^ Since the [1998 Russian financial crisis](/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis "1998 Russian financial crisis"), business sectors in Moscow have shown exponential rates of growth. Many new business centers and office buildings have been built in recent years, but Moscow still experiences shortages in office space. As a result, many former industrial and research facilities are being reconstructed to become suitable for office use. Overall, economic stability has improved in recent years; nonetheless, crime and corruption still hinder business development.{#cite_ref-175}  

### Industry {#Industry}

Primary [industries](/wiki/Industry_(economics) "Industry (economics)") in Moscow include the [chemical](/wiki/Chemical_industry "Chemical industry"), [metallurgy](/wiki/Metallurgy "Metallurgy"), [food](/wiki/Food_industry "Food industry"), [textile](/wiki/Textile "Textile"), [furniture](/wiki/Furniture "Furniture"), [energy production](/wiki/Energy_production "Energy production"), [software development](/wiki/Software_development "Software development") and [machinery](/wiki/Machine "Machine") industries.

The [Mil Moscow Helicopter Plant](/wiki/Mil_Moscow_Helicopter_Plant "Mil Moscow Helicopter Plant") is one of the world's leading producers of military and civil helicopters. [Khrunichev State Research and Production Space Center](/wiki/Khrunichev_State_Research_and_Production_Space_Center "Khrunichev State Research and Production Space Center") produces various space equipment, including modules for space stations [Mir](/wiki/Mir "Mir"), [Salyut](/wiki/Salyut "Salyut") and the [ISS](/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station") as well as [Proton launch vehicles](/wiki/Proton_(rocket) "Proton (rocket)") and military [ICBMs](/wiki/ICBM "ICBM"). [Sukhoi](/wiki/Sukhoi "Sukhoi"), [Ilyushin](/wiki/Ilyushin "Ilyushin"), [Mikoyan](/wiki/Mikoyan "Mikoyan"), [Tupolev](/wiki/Tupolev "Tupolev") and [Yakovlev](/wiki/Yakovlev "Yakovlev") aircraft design bureaus also situated in Moscow. [NPO Energomash](/wiki/NPO_Energomash "NPO Energomash"), producing the [rocket engines](/wiki/Rocket_engine "Rocket engine") for Russian and American space programs, as well as [Lavochkin](/wiki/Lavochkin "Lavochkin") design bureau, which built [fighter planes](/wiki/Fighter_plane "Fighter plane") during WWII, but switched to [space probes](/wiki/Space_probe "Space probe") since the [Space Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), are in nearby [Khimki](/wiki/Khimki "Khimki"), an independent city in [Moscow Oblast](/wiki/Moscow_Oblast "Moscow Oblast") that have largely been enclosed by Moscow from its sides. Automobile plants [ZiL](/wiki/ZiL "ZiL") and [AZLK](/wiki/AZLK "AZLK"), as well as the Voitovich Rail Vehicle plant, are situated in Moscow and [Metrovagonmash](/wiki/Metrovagonmash "Metrovagonmash") metro wagon plant is located just outside the city limits. The [Poljot Moscow watch factory](/wiki/Poljot "Poljot") produces military, professional and sport watches well known in Russia and abroad.

The Electrozavod factory was the first transformer factory in Russia. The Kristall distillery^[\[174\]](#cite_note-176)^ is the oldest distillery in Russia producing [vodka](/wiki/Vodka "Vodka") types, including "[Stolichnaya](/wiki/Stolichnaya "Stolichnaya")" while wines are produced at Moscow wine plants, including the Moscow Interrepublican Vinery.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-177)^ The Moscow Jewelry Factory^[\[176\]](#cite_note-178)^ and the Jewellerprom^[\[177\]](#cite_note-179)^ are producers of jewelry in Russia.{#cite_ref-179}

There are other industries located just outside the city of Moscow, as well as microelectronic industries in Zelenograd, including [Ruselectronics](/wiki/Ruselectronics "Ruselectronics") companies.

Gazprom, the largest extractor of [natural gas](/wiki/Natural_gas "Natural gas") in the world and the largest [Russian company](/wiki/Economy_of_Russia "Economy of Russia"), has head offices also in Moscow, as well as other oil, gas, and electricity companies.

Moscow hosts headquarters of the many of [telecommunications](/wiki/Telecommunications "Telecommunications") and [technology](/wiki/Technology_company "Technology company") companies, including [1C](/wiki/1C_Company "1C Company"), [ABBYY](/wiki/ABBYY "ABBYY"), [Beeline](/wiki/Beeline_(brand) "Beeline (brand)"), [Kaspersky Lab](/wiki/Kaspersky_Lab "Kaspersky Lab"), [Mail.Ru Group](/wiki/Mail.Ru "Mail.Ru"), [MegaFon](/wiki/MegaFon "MegaFon"), [MTS](/wiki/MTS_(network_provider) "MTS (network provider)"), [Rambler\&Co](/wiki/Rambler_(portal) "Rambler (portal)"), [Rostelecom](/wiki/Rostelecom "Rostelecom"), [Yandex](/wiki/Yandex "Yandex"), and [Yota](/wiki/Yota "Yota").

Some industry is being transferred out of the city to improve the ecological state of the city.  

### Cost of living {#Cost_of_living}

See also: [Hotels in Moscow](/wiki/Hotels_in_Moscow "Hotels in Moscow")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Moscow_09-13_img11_Tretyakovsky_Passage.jpg/170px-Moscow_09-13_img11_Tretyakovsky_Passage.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_09-13_img11_Tretyakovsky_Passage.jpg) [Tretyakovsky Proyezd](/wiki/Tretyakovsky_Proyezd "Tretyakovsky Proyezd") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/2019-07-25-3032-Moscow-Nikolskaya-Street.jpg/220px-2019-07-25-3032-Moscow-Nikolskaya-Street.jpg)](/wiki/File:2019-07-25-3032-Moscow-Nikolskaya-Street.jpg) [Nikolskaya Street](/wiki/Nikolskaya_Street "Nikolskaya Street") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Mitino-3_from_d40_2011-09N28.jpg/220px-Mitino-3_from_d40_2011-09N28.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mitino-3_from_d40_2011-09N28.jpg) A [microdistrict](/wiki/Microdistrict "Microdistrict") in [Mitino](/wiki/Mitino_District "Mitino District") built in the 1990s

During [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") times, apartments were lent to people by the government according to the square meters-per-person norm (some groups, including people's artists, heroes, and prominent scientists had bonuses according to their honors). [Private ownership](/wiki/Private_ownership "Private ownership") of apartments was limited until the 1990s when people were permitted to secure property rights to their inhabited places. Since the Soviet era, estate owners have had to pay the service charge for their residences, a fixed amount based on persons per living area.

The price of [real estate](/wiki/Real_estate "Real estate") in Moscow continues to rise. Today, one could expect to pay $4,000 on average per square meter (11 sq ft) on the outskirts of the city^[\[178\]](#cite_note-180)^ or US$6,500--$8,000 per square meter in a prestigious district. The price sometimes may exceed US$40,000 per square meter in a flat.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-181)^^[\[180\]](#cite_note-182)^^[\[181\]](#cite_note-183)^ It costs about US$1,200 per month to rent a one-bedroom apartment and about US$1,000 per month for a studio in the center of Moscow.{#cite_ref-183}

A typical one-bedroom apartment is about thirty square metres (320 [square feet](/wiki/Square_foot "Square foot")), a typical two-bedroom apartment is forty-five square metres (480 square feet), and a typical three-bedroom apartment is seventy square metres (750 square feet). Many cannot move out of their apartments, especially if a family lives in a two-room apartment originally granted by the state during the Soviet era. Some city residents have attempted to cope with the cost of living by renting their apartments while staying in [dachas](/wiki/Dacha "Dacha") (country houses) outside the city.

In 2006, Mercer Human Resources Consulting named Moscow the world's [most expensive city for expatriate employees](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_cities_for_expatriate_employees "List of most expensive cities for expatriate employees"), ahead of perennial winner Tokyo, due to the stable [Russian ruble](/wiki/Russian_ruble "Russian ruble") as well as increasing housing prices within the city.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-184)^ Moscow also ranked first in the 2007 edition and 2008 edition of the survey. However, Tokyo has overtaken Moscow as the most expensive city in the world, placing Moscow at third behind Osaka in second place.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-mercer.com-185)^{#cite_ref-mercer.com_185-0}

In 2008, Moscow ranked top on the [list of most expensive cities](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_cities "List of most expensive cities") for the third year in a row.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}

In 2014, according to *Forbes* , Moscow was ranked the 9th most expensive city in the world. *Forbes* ranked Moscow the 2nd most expensive city the year prior.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-187)^{#cite_ref-187}

In 2019 the Economist Intelligence Unit's Worldwide Cost of Living survey put Moscow to 102nd place in the biannual ranking of 133 most expensive cities.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-188)^ ECA International's Cost of Living 2019 Survey ranked Moscow at number 120 among 482 locations worldwide.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}  

### Public utilities {#Public_utilities}

The heating of buildings in Moscow, like in other cities in Russia is done using [central heating system](/wiki/District_heating "District heating"). Before 2004, state [unitary enterprises](/wiki/Unitary_enterprise "Unitary enterprise") were responsible to produce and supply heat to the clients by the operation of heating stations and heating distribution system of Mosgorteplo, Mosteploenergo, and Teploremontnaladka which gave service to the [heating substations](/wiki/District_heating_substation "District heating substation") in the [north-eastern part](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Moscow "Administrative divisions of Moscow") of the city. Clients were divided between the various enterprises based on their geographical location. A major reform launched in 2004 consolidated the various companies under the umbrella of MIPC which became the municipal heat supplier. Its subsidiaries were the newly transformed Joint-stock companies. The city's main source of heating is the power station of Mosenergo which was reformed in 2005, when around ten subsidiaries were separated from it. One of the newly independent companies was the District Heating Network Company (MTK) ([Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): Московская теплосетевая компания). In 2007 the [Government of Moscow](/wiki/Government_of_Moscow "Government of Moscow") bought controlling stakes in the company.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}

"Our city" is a geo-information portal created in 2011 under the mayor of Moscow Sergei Sobyanin with the aim of building a constructive dialogue between Moscow residents and the city's executive authorities. The portal is being developed by the State Public Institution "New Management Technologies" together with the Moscow Department of Information Technologies. In its 10 years of operation, more than 1.7 million users have joined the portal, and during this time it has become an effective tool for monitoring the state of urban infrastructure.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-191)^{#cite_ref-191}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

Further information: [Education in Russia](/wiki/Education_in_Russia "Education in Russia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3,_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg) [Moscow State University](/wiki/Moscow_State_University "Moscow State University")

There are 1,696 high schools in Moscow, as well as 91 colleges.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-mosru-stats-127)^ Besides these, there are 222 institutions of higher education, including 60 state universities^[\[125\]](#cite_note-mosru-stats-127)^ and the [Lomonosov Moscow State University](/wiki/Moscow_State_University "Moscow State University"), which was founded in 1755.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-msu-history-192)^ The main university building located in Vorobyovy Gory ([Sparrow Hills](/wiki/Sparrow_Hills "Sparrow Hills")) is 240 metres (790 ft) tall and when completed, was the tallest building on the continent.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-193)^ The university has over 30,000 [undergraduate](/wiki/Undergraduate_education "Undergraduate education") and 7,000 [postgraduate](/wiki/Postgraduate_education "Postgraduate education") students, who have a choice of twenty-nine faculties and 450 departments for study. The Moscow State University library contains over nine million books, making it one of the largest libraries in all of Russia.{#cite_ref-193}

The [I.M. Sechenov First Moscow State Medical University](/wiki/I.M._Sechenov_First_Moscow_State_Medical_University "I.M. Sechenov First Moscow State Medical University") named after [Ivan Sechenov](/wiki/Ivan_Sechenov "Ivan Sechenov") or formerly known as [Moscow Medical Academy](/wiki/Moscow_Medical_Academy "Moscow Medical Academy") (1stMSMU) is a medical university situated in Moscow, Russia. It was founded in 1785 as the faculty of the Moscow State University. It is a Russian Federal Agency for Health and Social Development. It is one of the largest medical universities in Russia and Europe. More than 9200 students are enrolled in 115 academic departments. It offers courses for post-graduate studies.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Pirogov_Russian_National_Research_Medical_University_Frontal_View.jpg/220px-Pirogov_Russian_National_Research_Medical_University_Frontal_View.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pirogov_Russian_National_Research_Medical_University_Frontal_View.jpg) [Pirogov Russian National Research Medical University](/wiki/Pirogov_Russian_National_Research_Medical_University "Pirogov Russian National Research Medical University")

The [Pirogov Russian National Research Medical University](/wiki/Pirogov_Russian_National_Research_Medical_University "Pirogov Russian National Research Medical University") (formerly known as [Russian State Medical University](/wiki/Russian_State_Medical_University "Russian State Medical University")) is a medical higher education institution in Moscow, Russia founded in 1906. It is fully accredited and recognized by Russia's Ministry of Education and Science and is currently under the authority of the Ministry of Health and Social Development. Named after Russian surgeon and pedagogue [N.I. Pirogov](/wiki/Nikolay_Pirogov "Nikolay Pirogov") (1810--1888), it is one of the largest medical institutions and the first university in Russia to allow women to acquire degrees.

Moscow is one of the financial centers of the [Russian Federation](/wiki/Russian_Federation "Russian Federation") and [CIS](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States "Commonwealth of Independent States") countries and is known for its business schools. Among them are the [Financial University under the Government of the Russian Federation](/wiki/Financial_University_under_the_Government_of_the_Russian_Federation "Financial University under the Government of the Russian Federation"); [Plekhanov Russian University of Economics](/wiki/Plekhanov_Russian_University_of_Economics "Plekhanov Russian University of Economics"); [The State University of Management](/wiki/The_State_University_of_Management "The State University of Management"), and the [National Research University - Higher School of Economics](/wiki/National_Research_University_-_Higher_School_of_Economics "National Research University - Higher School of Economics"). They offer undergraduate degrees in management, finance, accounting, marketing, real estate, and economic theory, as well as Masters programs and [MBAs](/wiki/MBA "MBA"). Most of them have branches in other regions of Russia and countries around the world.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Moscow_MSTU_Bauman_main_building_asv2021-08.jpg/220px-Moscow_MSTU_Bauman_main_building_asv2021-08.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_MSTU_Bauman_main_building_asv2021-08.jpg) The main building of the [Bauman Moscow State Technical University](/wiki/Bauman_Moscow_State_Technical_University "Bauman Moscow State Technical University")

[Bauman Moscow State Technical University](/wiki/Bauman_Moscow_State_Technical_University "Bauman Moscow State Technical University"), founded in 1830, is located in the center of Moscow and provides 18,000 undergraduate and 1,000 postgraduate students with an education in science and engineering, offering technical degrees.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-194)^{#cite_ref-194}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Moscow_05-2017_img41_Conservatory.jpg/220px-Moscow_05-2017_img41_Conservatory.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_05-2017_img41_Conservatory.jpg) The [Moscow Conservatory](/wiki/Moscow_Conservatory "Moscow Conservatory") building

The [Moscow Conservatory](/wiki/Moscow_Conservatory "Moscow Conservatory"),^[\[193\]](#cite_note-195)^ founded in 1866, is a prominent music school in Russia.{#cite_ref-195}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vgik.jpg/220px-Vgik.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vgik.jpg) The [Russian State Institute of Cinematography](/wiki/Gerasimov_Institute_of_Cinematography "Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography"), the world's oldest   
[film school](/wiki/Film_school "Film school")

The [Gerasimov All-Russian State Institute of Cinematography](/wiki/Gerasimov_Institute_of_Cinematography "Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography"), abbreviated as VGIK, is the world's oldest educational institution in [Cinematography](/wiki/Cinematography "Cinematography"), founded by [Vladimir Gardin](/wiki/Vladimir_Gardin "Vladimir Gardin") in 1919.

[Moscow State Institute of International Relations](/wiki/Moscow_State_Institute_of_International_Relations "Moscow State Institute of International Relations"), founded in 1944, remains Russia's best- known school of international relations and diplomacy, with six schools focused on international relations. Approximately 4,500 students make up the university's student body and over 700,000 Russian and foreign-language books---of which 20,000 are considered rare---can be found in the library of the Moscow State Institute of International Relations.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-196)^{#cite_ref-196}

Other institutions are the [Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology](/wiki/Moscow_Institute_of_Physics_and_Technology "Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology"), also known as [Phystech](/wiki/Phystech "Phystech"), the [Fyodorov Eye Microsurgery Complex](/wiki/Fyodorov_Eye_Microsurgery_Complex "Fyodorov Eye Microsurgery Complex"), founded in 1988 by Russian eye surgeon [Svyatoslav Fyodorov](/wiki/Svyatoslav_Fyodorov "Svyatoslav Fyodorov"), the [Moscow Aviation Institute](/wiki/Moscow_Aviation_Institute "Moscow Aviation Institute"), the Moscow Motorway Institute (State Technical University), and the [Moscow Engineering Physics Institute](/wiki/Moscow_Engineering_Physics_Institute "Moscow Engineering Physics Institute"). [Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology](/wiki/Moscow_Institute_of_Physics_and_Technology "Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology") has taught numerous [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") winners, including [Pyotr Kapitsa](/wiki/Pyotr_Kapitsa "Pyotr Kapitsa"), [Nikolay Semyonov](/wiki/Nikolay_Semyonov "Nikolay Semyonov"), [Lev Landau](/wiki/Lev_Landau "Lev Landau") and [Alexander Prokhorov](/wiki/Alexander_Prokhorov "Alexander Prokhorov"), while the [Moscow Engineering Physics Institute](/wiki/Moscow_Engineering_Physics_Institute "Moscow Engineering Physics Institute") is known for its research in [nuclear physics](/wiki/Nuclear_physics "Nuclear physics").^[\[195\]](#cite_note-197)^ The highest Russian military school is the [Combined Arms Academy of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation](/wiki/Combined_Arms_Academy_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_Russian_Federation "Combined Arms Academy of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation").{#cite_ref-197}

Although Moscow has a number of famous Soviet-era higher educational institutions, most of which are more oriented towards engineering or the fundamental sciences, in recent years Moscow has seen a growth in the number of commercial and private institutions that offer classes in business and management. Many state institutions have expanded their education scope and introduced new courses or departments. Institutions in Moscow, as well as the rest of post-Soviet Russia, have begun to offer new international certificates and postgraduate degrees, including the [Master of Business Administration](/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration "Master of Business Administration"). [Student exchange programs](/wiki/Student_exchange_program "Student exchange program") with numerous countries, specially with the rest of Europe, have also become widespread in Moscow's universities, while schools within the Russian capital also offer seminars, lectures, and courses for corporate employees and businessmen.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Moscow_1152_%2814384525084%29.jpg/170px-Moscow_1152_%2814384525084%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_1152_(14384525084).jpg) [Russian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Sciences "Russian Academy of Sciences")

Moscow is one of the largest science centers in Russia. The headquarters of the [Russian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Sciences "Russian Academy of Sciences") are located in Moscow as well as research and applied science institutions. The [Kurchatov Institute](/wiki/Kurchatov_Institute "Kurchatov Institute"), Russia's leading research and development institution in the fields of nuclear energy, where the first [nuclear reactor](/wiki/Nuclear_reactor "Nuclear reactor") in Europe was built, the [Landau Institute for Theoretical Physics](/wiki/Landau_Institute_for_Theoretical_Physics "Landau Institute for Theoretical Physics"), [Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics](/wiki/Institute_for_Theoretical_and_Experimental_Physics "Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics"), [Kapitza Institute for Physical Problems](/wiki/Institute_for_Physical_Problems "Institute for Physical Problems") and [Steklov Institute of Mathematics](/wiki/Steklov_Institute_of_Mathematics "Steklov Institute of Mathematics") are all situated in Moscow.

There are 452 libraries in the city, including 168 for children.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-mosru-stats-127)^ The [Russian State Library](/wiki/Russian_State_Library "Russian State Library"),^[\[196\]](#cite_note-198)^ founded in 1862, is the national library of Russia. The library is home to over 275 km (171 mi) of shelves and 42 million items, including over 17 million books and serial volumes, 13 million journals, 350,000 music scores and sound records, and 150,000 maps, making it the largest library in Russia and one of the largest in the world. Items in 247 languages account for 29% of the collection.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-199)^^[\[198\]](#cite_note-200)^{#cite_ref-200}

The State Public Historical Library, founded in 1863, is the largest library specialising in [Russian history](/wiki/Russian_history "Russian history"). Its collection contains four million items in 112 languages, mostly on Russian and world history, [heraldry](/wiki/Heraldry "Heraldry"), [numismatics](/wiki/Numismatics "Numismatics"), and the [history of science](/wiki/History_of_science "History of science").^[\[199\]](#cite_note-201)^{#cite_ref-201}

In regard to primary and secondary education, in 2011, [Clifford J. Levy](/wiki/Clifford_J._Levy "Clifford J. Levy") of *[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")* wrote, "Moscow has some strong public schools, but the system as a whole is dispiriting, in part because it is being corroded by the corruption that is a post-Soviet scourge. Parents often pay bribes to get their children admitted to better public schools. There are additional payoffs for good grades."^[\[200\]](#cite_note-Levy1-202)^{#cite_ref-Levy1_202-0}  

Transportation {#Transportation}
--------------------------------

Main article: [Transportation in Moscow](/wiki/Transportation_in_Moscow "Transportation in Moscow")  

### Metro {#Metro}

Main article: [Moscow Metro](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Moscow_metro_map_sb.svg/220px-Moscow_metro_map_sb.svg.png)](/w/index.php?title=File:Moscow_metro_map_sb.svg&lang=en) [Moscow Metro](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro") route map with planned stations [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Moscow_MayakovskayaMetroStation_0943.jpg/240px-Moscow_MayakovskayaMetroStation_0943.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_MayakovskayaMetroStation_0943.jpg) [Mayakovskaya](/wiki/Mayakovskaya_(Moscow_Metro) "Mayakovskaya (Moscow Metro)") station, opened in 1938

The [Moscow Metro](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro") system is famous for its art, [murals](/wiki/Mural "Mural"), [mosaics](/wiki/Mosaic "Mosaic"), and ornate [chandeliers](/wiki/Chandelier "Chandelier"). It started operation in 1935 and immediately became the centrepiece of the transportation system. More than that it was a Stalinist device to awe and reward the populace, and give them an appreciation of Soviet realist art. It became the prototype for future Soviet large-scale technologies. [Lazar Kaganovich](/wiki/Lazar_Kaganovich "Lazar Kaganovich") was in charge; he designed the subway so that citizens would absorb the values and ethos of Stalinist civilisation as they rode. The artwork of the 13 original stations became nationally and internationally famous. For example, the Sverdlov Square subway station featured porcelain bas-reliefs depicting the daily life of the Soviet peoples, and the bas-reliefs at the Dynamo Stadium sports complex glorified sports and the physical prowess of the powerful new "Homo Sovieticus" (Soviet man).^[\[201\]](#cite_note-203)^{#cite_ref-203}

The metro was touted as the symbol of the new social order---a sort of Communist cathedral of engineering modernity.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-204)^ Soviet workers did the labour and the artwork, but the main engineering designs, routes, and construction plans were handled by specialists recruited from the London Underground. The Britons called for tunneling instead of the "cut-and-cover" technique, the use of escalators instead of lifts, and designed the routes and the rolling stock.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-205)^ The paranoia of Stalin and the NKVD was evident when the secret police arrested numerous British engineers for espionage---that is for gaining an in-depth knowledge of the city's physical layout. Engineers for the Metropolitan Vickers Electrical Company were given a show trial and deported in 1933, ending the role of British business in the USSR.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-206)^{#cite_ref-206}

Today, the Moscow Metro comprises twelve lines, mostly underground with a total of 203 stations. The Metro is one of the deepest subway systems in the world; for instance, the [Park Pobedy](/wiki/Park_Pobedy_(Moscow_Metro) "Park Pobedy (Moscow Metro)") station, completed in 2003, at 84 metres (276 ft) underground, has the longest escalators in Europe. The Moscow Metro is the busiest metro system in Europe, as well as [one of the world's busiest](/wiki/Metro_systems_by_annual_passenger_rides "Metro systems by annual passenger rides") metro systems, serving about ten million passengers daily (300,000,000 people every month).^[\[205\]](#cite_note-metro-207)^ Facing serious transportation problems, Moscow has plans for expanding its Metro. In 2016, the authorities launched a [new circle metro railway](/wiki/Moscow_Central_Circle "Moscow Central Circle") that contributed to solving transportation issues, namely daily congestion at Koltsevaya Line.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-208)^{#cite_ref-208}

Due to the treatment of Metro stations as possible canvas for art, characterized by the fact that workers of Moscow would get to see them every day, many Stalin-era metro stations were built in different "custom" designs (where each station's design would be, initially, a massive installation on a certain theme. For example, [Elektrozavodskaya](/wiki/Elektrozavodskaya_(Arbatsko%E2%80%93Pokrovskaya_line) "Elektrozavodskaya (Arbatsko–Pokrovskaya line)") station was themed solely after nearby lightbulb factory and ceramic ribbed lightbulb sockets);^[\[207\]](#cite_note-209)^ the tradition of "Grand Designs" and, basically, decorating metro stations as single-themed installations, was restored in late 1979.{#cite_ref-209}

Moscow's metro is one of the world's busiest, handling 2.6 billion passengers in 2019.^[\[208\]](#cite_note-210)^{#cite_ref-210}

In the Russian capital, there are over 21.5 thousand Wi-Fi access points, in student dormitories, in parks, cultural and sports institutions, and within the Garden Ring and the Third Transport Ring. From September 2020 to August 2021, 1,700 new access points to urban Wi-Fi were launched in Moscow.^[\[209\]](#cite_note-211)^ The structure of the Wi-Fi network allows citizens to use the Internet without re-authorization.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-212)^{#cite_ref-212}  

### Monorail {#Monorail}

Main article: [Moscow Monorail](/wiki/Moscow_Monorail "Moscow Monorail")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Monorail_Moskau_-_Einfahrt_in_Station_Telezentrum.jpg/220px-Monorail_Moskau_-_Einfahrt_in_Station_Telezentrum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Monorail_Moskau_-_Einfahrt_in_Station_Telezentrum.jpg) Two trains of the [Moscow Monorail](/wiki/Moscow_Monorail "Moscow Monorail")

The Moscow Metro operates a short [monorail line](/wiki/Moscow_Monorail "Moscow Monorail") (line 13). The line connects [Timiryazevskaya](/wiki/Timiryazevskaya_(Serpukhovsko-Timiryazevskaya_Line) "Timiryazevskaya (Serpukhovsko-Timiryazevskaya Line)") metro station and [Ulitsa Sergeya Eisensteina](/wiki/Ulitsa_Sergeya_Eisensteina "Ulitsa Sergeya Eisensteina"), passing close to [VDNH](/wiki/Exhibition_of_Achievements_of_National_Economy "Exhibition of Achievements of National Economy") (and Line 6 Metro station "V.D.N.Kh."). The line opened in 2004. It accepts overground interchanges, no additional fare is needed if a ride was spent at Moscow Metro within previous 90 minutes.  

### Bus, trolleybus and electric bus {#Bus.2C_trolleybus_and_electric_bus}

Main article: [Electric buses in Moscow](/wiki/Electric_buses_in_Moscow "Electric buses in Moscow")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/%D0%92%D1%8B%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B4_500-%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D1%8D%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8E_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B5_%2809%29.jpg/220px-%D0%92%D1%8B%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B4_500-%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D1%8D%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8E_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B5_%2809%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%92%D1%8B%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B4_500-%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D1%8D%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8E_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B5_(09).jpg) Moscow has the [largest fleet of electric buses](/wiki/Electric_buses_in_Moscow "Electric buses in Moscow") in Europe, with 500 operating as of October 2020^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Moscow&action=edit)^.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-Trolleybus-213)^

As Metro stations outside the city center are far apart in comparison to other cities, up to 4 kilometres (2.5 mi), a bus network radiates from each station to the surrounding residential zones. Moscow has a bus terminal for long-range and intercity passenger buses ([Central Bus Terminal](/wiki/Moscow_Central_Bus_Terminal "Moscow Central Bus Terminal")) with a daily turnover of about 25 thousand passengers serving about 40% of long-range bus routes in Moscow.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-214)^{#cite_ref-214}

Every major street in the city is served by at least one bus route. Many of these routes are doubled by a [trolleybus](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus") route and have trolley wires over them.

With the total line length of almost 600 kilometres (370 miles) of a single wire, 8 depots, 104 routes, and 1740 vehicles, the Moscow trolleybus system was the [largest in the world](/wiki/Trolleybus_usage_by_country "Trolleybus usage by country"). But municipal authority, headed by Sergey Sobyanin, began to destroy the trolleybus system in Moscow in 2014 due the planned replacement of trolleybuses by electric buses. In 2018 Moscow trolleybus system has only 4 depots and dozens of kilometers of unused wires. Almost all trolleybus wires inside Garden Ring (Sadovoe Koltso) were cut in 2016--2017 due to the reconstruction of central streets ("Moya Ulitsa"). Opened on 15 November 1933, it is also the world's 6th oldest operating trolleybus system.

In 2018 the vehicle companies [Kamaz](/wiki/Kamaz "Kamaz") and [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ") have won the [Mosgortrans](/wiki/Mosgortrans "Mosgortrans") tender for delivering 200 [electric buses](/wiki/Electric_bus "Electric bus") and 62 ultra-fast charging stations to the city transport system. The manufacturers will be responsible for the quality and reliable operation of the buses and charging stations for the next 15 years. The city will be procuring only electric buses as of 2021, replacing the diesel bus fleet gradually. According to expectations, Moscow will become the leader amongst the European cities in terms of electric and gas fuel share in public transport by 2019.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-215)^{#cite_ref-215}  

### Moscow cable car {#Moscow_cable_car}

Main article: [Moskva River cable car](/wiki/Moskva_River_cable_car "Moskva River cable car")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Moscow_Cable_Car.jpg/220px-Moscow_Cable_Car.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_Cable_Car.jpg) Cable cars passing across the [Moskva River](/wiki/Moskva_River "Moskva River") and the [Luzhniki Stadium](/wiki/Luzhniki_Stadium "Luzhniki Stadium")

On 26 November 2018, the [mayor of Moscow](/wiki/Mayor_of_Moscow "Mayor of Moscow") [Sergey Sobyanin](/wiki/Sergey_Sobyanin "Sergey Sobyanin") took part in the ceremony to open the [cable car](/wiki/Moskva_River_cable_car "Moskva River cable car") above the [Moskva River](/wiki/Moskva_River "Moskva River"). The cable car will connect the [Luzhniki sports complex](/wiki/Luzhniki_Olympic_Complex "Luzhniki Olympic Complex") with [Sparrow Hills](/wiki/Sparrow_Hills "Sparrow Hills") and Kosygin Street. The journey from the well-known viewpoint on Vorobyovy Gory to [Luzhniki Stadium](/wiki/Luzhniki_Stadium "Luzhniki Stadium") will last for five minutes instead of 20 minutes that one would have to spend on the same journey by car.  

### Tram {#Tram}

Main article: [Trams in Moscow](/wiki/Trams_in_Moscow "Trams in Moscow")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Moscow_TverZastava_Vityaz_asv2018-09.jpg/220px-Moscow_TverZastava_Vityaz_asv2018-09.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_TverZastava_Vityaz_asv2018-09.jpg) A Vityaz-M tram passing by the [Tverskaya Zastava Square](/wiki/Tverskaya_Zastava_Square "Tverskaya Zastava Square")

Moscow has an extensive tram system, which first opened in 1899.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-216)^ The newest line was built in 1984. Its daily usage by Muscovites is low, making up for approximately 5% of trips because many vital connections in the network have been withdrawn. Trams still remain important in some districts as feeders to Metro stations. The trams also provide important cross-links between metro lines, for example between [Universitet station](/wiki/Universitet_(Moscow_Metro) "Universitet (Moscow Metro)") of [Sokolnicheskaya Line](/wiki/Sokolnicheskaya_Line "Sokolnicheskaya Line") (#1 red line) and [Profsoyuznaya station](/wiki/Profsoyuznaya_(Moscow_Metro) "Profsoyuznaya (Moscow Metro)") of [Kaluzhsko-Rizhskaya Line](/wiki/Kaluzhsko-Rizhskaya_Line "Kaluzhsko-Rizhskaya Line") (#6 orange line) or between [Voykovskaya](/wiki/Voykovskaya_(Moscow_Metro) "Voykovskaya (Moscow Metro)") and [Strogino](/wiki/Strogino_(Moscow_Metro) "Strogino (Moscow Metro)").{#cite_ref-216}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Moscow_tram_map_2022-04.svg/220px-Moscow_tram_map_2022-04.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moscow_tram_map_2022-04.svg) Tram map of Moscow

There are three tram networks in the city:

* Krasnopresnenskoye depot network with the westernmost point at Strogino (depot location) and the easternmost point near platform Dmitrovskaya. This network became separated in 1973, but until 1997 it could easily have been reconnected by about one kilometre (fifty chains) of track and three switches. The network has the highest usage in Moscow and no weak points based on turnover except to-depot lane (passengers serviced by bus) and tram ring at Dmitrovskaya (because now it is neither a normal transfer point nor a repair terminal).
* The Apakov depot services the south-western part from the Varshavsky lane -- Simferopolsky boulevard in the east to the Universitet station in the west and Boulevard lane at the center. This network is connected only by the four-way Dubininskaya and Kozhevnicheskaya streets. A second connection by Vostochnaya (Eastern) street was withdrawn in 1987 due to a fire at the Dinamo plant and has not been recovered, and remains lost (Avtozavodsky bridge) at 1992. The network may be serviced anyway by another depot (now route 35, 38).
* Main three depot networks with railway gate and tram-repair plant.

In addition, tram advocates have suggested that the new rapid transit services (metro to City, Butovo light metro, Monorail) would be more effective as at-grade tram lines and that the problems with trams are only due to poor management and operation, not the technical properties of trams. New tram models have been developed for the Moscow network despite the lack of expansion.  

### Taxi {#Taxi}

Commercial taxi services and [route taxis](/wiki/Route_taxi "Route taxi") are in widespread use. In the mid-2010s, service platforms such as [Yandex.Taxi](/wiki/Yandex.Taxi "Yandex.Taxi"), [Uber](/wiki/Uber "Uber") and [Gett](/wiki/Gett "Gett") displaced many private drivers and small service providers and were in 2015 servicing more than 50% of all taxi orders in Moscow.^[\[215\]](#cite_note-217)^^[\[216\]](#cite_note-218)^{#cite_ref-218}

Russian tech firm Yandex is testing self-driving taxis in Moscow.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-219)^{#cite_ref-219}  

### Railway {#Railway}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Komsomolskaya_square_as_seen_from_Leningradskaya_hotel_in_winter_%282014%29_-%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%89%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%8C_%D0%B8%D0%B7_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B_%D0%9B%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg)](/wiki/File:Komsomolskaya_square_as_seen_from_Leningradskaya_hotel_in_winter_(2014)_-%D0%92%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%89%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%8C_%D0%B8%D0%B7_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B_%D0%9B%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_-_panoramio.jpg) [Komsomolskaya Square](/wiki/Komsomolskaya_Square_(Moscow) "Komsomolskaya Square (Moscow)") known as "Three Station Square" thanks to three ornate rail terminal situated there: [Leningradsky](/wiki/Moscow_Passazhirskaya_railway_station "Moscow Passazhirskaya railway station"), [Yaroslavsky](/wiki/Moscow_Yaroslavskaya_railway_station "Moscow Yaroslavskaya railway station"), and [Kazansky](/wiki/Moscow_Kazanskaya_railway_station "Moscow Kazanskaya railway station").

Several train stations serve the city. Moscow's ten rail terminals (or *vokzals*) are:

* [Belorussky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Belorussky_Rail_Terminal "Belorussky Rail Terminal")
* [Kazansky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Kazansky_Rail_Terminal "Kazansky Rail Terminal")
* [Kiyevsky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Kiyevsky_Rail_Terminal "Kiyevsky Rail Terminal")
* [Kursky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Kursky_Rail_Terminal "Kursky Rail Terminal")
* [Leningradsky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Leningradsky_Rail_Terminal "Leningradsky Rail Terminal")
* [Paveletsky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Paveletsky_Rail_Terminal "Paveletsky Rail Terminal")
* [Rizhsky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Rizhsky_Rail_Terminal "Rizhsky Rail Terminal")
* [Savyolovsky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Savyolovsky_Rail_Terminal "Savyolovsky Rail Terminal")
* [Yaroslavsky Rail Terminal](/wiki/Yaroslavsky_Rail_Terminal "Yaroslavsky Rail Terminal")
* [Vostochny railway Terminal](/wiki/Vostochny_Railway_Terminal_(Moscow) "Vostochny Railway Terminal (Moscow)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Bullet-Train.jpg/220px-Bullet-Train.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bullet-Train.jpg) The high-speed [Sapsan](/wiki/Sapsan "Sapsan") train links Moscow with [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg").

The terminals are located close to the city center, along with the metro ringline 5 or close to it, and connect to a metro line to the centre of town. Each station handles trains from different parts of Europe and Asia.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-mostimestrain-220)^ There are many smaller railway stations in Moscow. As train tickets are cheap, they are the preferred mode of travel for Russians, especially when departing to Saint Petersburg, Russia's second-largest city. Moscow is the western terminus of the [Trans-Siberian Railway](/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway "Trans-Siberian Railway"), which traverses nearly 9,300 kilometres (5,800 mi) of Russian territory to [Vladivostok](/wiki/Vladivostok "Vladivostok") on the [Pacific](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") coast.{#cite_ref-mostimestrain_220-0}

Suburbs and satellite cities are connected by commuter [elektrichka](/wiki/Elektrichka "Elektrichka") (electric rail) network. Elektrichkas depart from each of these terminals to the nearby (up to 140 km or 87 mi) large railway stations.

During the 2010s, the [Little Ring of the Moscow Railway](/wiki/Little_Ring_of_the_Moscow_Railway "Little Ring of the Moscow Railway") was converted to be used for frequent passenger service; it is fully integrated with Moscow Metro; the passenger service started on 10 September 2016. A connecting railway line on the North side of the town connects Belorussky terminal with other railway lines. This is used by some suburban trains.  

#### Moscow Central Circle {#Moscow_Central_Circle}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/MCC_12LUZH_7041_PLAT.jpg/220px-MCC_12LUZH_7041_PLAT.jpg)](/wiki/File:MCC_12LUZH_7041_PLAT.jpg) "Lastochka" train on "[Luzhniki](/wiki/Luzhniki_(Moscow_Central_Circle) "Luzhniki (Moscow Central Circle)")" station (Line 14)

The [Moskovskaya Okruzhnaya Zheleznaya Doroga](/wiki/Little_Ring_of_the_Moscow_Railway "Little Ring of the Moscow Railway") formed a ring around the now-downtown Moscow since 1903, but only served as a non-electrified, fueled locomotive-only railway prior to reconstruction into MCC in 2010's.

The [Moscow Central Circle](/wiki/Moscow_Central_Circle "Moscow Central Circle") is a 54-kilometre-long (34 mi) [urban-metro railway](/wiki/Urban_rail_transit "Urban rail transit") orbital line that encircles historical Moscow. It was built alongside [Little Ring of the Moscow Railway](/wiki/Little_Ring_of_the_Moscow_Railway "Little Ring of the Moscow Railway"), taking some of its tracks into itself as well. M.C.C. was opened for passenger use on 10 September 2016.

The line is operated by the [Moscow Government](/wiki/Moscow_Government "Moscow Government") owned company MKZD through the [Moscow Metro](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro"), with the [Federal Government](/wiki/Government_of_Russia "Government of Russia") owned [Russian Railways](/wiki/Russian_Railways "Russian Railways") selected as the operation subcontractor.  

#### Moscow Central Diameters {#Moscow_Central_Diameters}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/EG2Tv_arrives_to_Belorussky_rail_terminal_%28platform_4%29.jpg/220px-EG2Tv_arrives_to_Belorussky_rail_terminal_%28platform_4%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:EG2Tv_arrives_to_Belorussky_rail_terminal_(platform_4).jpg) An [EG2Tv](/wiki/Ivolga_(train) "Ivolga (train)") train arriving at the [Moscow Belorussky railway station](/wiki/Moscow_Belorussky_railway_station "Moscow Belorussky railway station") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Moscow_Central_Diameters_-_passenger_scheme1.jpg/220px-Moscow_Central_Diameters_-_passenger_scheme1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_Central_Diameters_-_passenger_scheme1.jpg) Map of the [Moscow Central Diameters](/wiki/Moscow_Central_Diameters "Moscow Central Diameters")

Another system, which forms "genuine *S-Bahn* " as in "suburbia-city-suburbia"-designed railway, is the [Moscow Central Diameters](/wiki/Moscow_Central_Diameters "Moscow Central Diameters"), a pass-through railways system, created by constructing bypasses from "vokzals" final stations (e.g. by avoiding the central stations of already existing Moscow Railway, used for both intercity and urban-suburban travel before)^[\[219\]](#cite_note-221)^ and forming a train line across Moscow's centre.{#cite_ref-221}

Out of 5 projected lines, the first 2 lines were completed and launched on 2019-11-21.  

### Roads {#Roads}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%89%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%8C_%D0%A2%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%97%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0_%28%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%85%D1%83%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%89%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%8C_%D0%A2%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%97%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0_%28%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%85%D1%83%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%89%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%8C_%D0%A2%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%97%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0_(%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%85%D1%83).jpg) Intersection at [Tverskaya Zastava Square](/wiki/Tverskaya_Zastava_Square "Tverskaya Zastava Square")

There are over 2.6 million cars in the city daily. Recent years have seen growth in the number of cars, which have caused traffic jams and lack of parking space to become major problems.

The Moscow Ring Road (MKAD), along with the [Third Transport Ring](/wiki/Third_Ring_Road_(Moscow) "Third Ring Road (Moscow)") and the canceled Fourth Transport Ring, is one of only three freeways that run within Moscow city limits. Several other roadway systems form [concentric circles](/wiki/Concentric_circles "Concentric circles") around the city.  

### Air {#Air}

There are five primary commercial airports serving Moscow: [Sheremetyevo](/wiki/Sheremetyevo_International_Airport "Sheremetyevo International Airport") (SVO), [Domodedovo](/wiki/Domodedovo_International_Airport "Domodedovo International Airport") (DME), [Vnukovo](/wiki/Vnukovo_International_Airport "Vnukovo International Airport") (VKO), [Zhukovsky](/wiki/Zhukovsky_International_Airport "Zhukovsky International Airport") (ZIA), [Ostafyevo](/wiki/Ostafyevo_International_Airport "Ostafyevo International Airport") (OSF).
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg/220px-Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg)](/wiki/File:Airbus_A319-112,_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg) Sheremetyevo, the [busiest airport in Russia](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Russia "List of the busiest airports in Russia"), is ranked as the [eleventh-busiest airport](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Europe "List of the busiest airports in Europe") in Europe.

Sheremetyevo International Airport is the most globally connected of Moscow's airports, handling 60% of all international flights.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-4airports-222)^ It is also a home to all [SkyTeam](/wiki/SkyTeam "SkyTeam") members, and the main hub for [Aeroflot](/wiki/Aeroflot "Aeroflot") (itself a member of SkyTeam). Domodedovo International Airport is the leading airport in Russia in terms of passenger throughput and is the primary gateway to long-haul domestic and CIS destinations and its international traffic rivals Sheremetyevo. It is a hub for [S7 airlines](/wiki/S7_airlines "S7 airlines"), and most of [OneWorld](/wiki/OneWorld "OneWorld") and [Star Alliance](/wiki/Star_Alliance "Star Alliance") members use Domodedovo as their international hub. Vnukovo International Airport handles flights of [Turkish Airlines](/wiki/Turkish_Airlines "Turkish Airlines"), [Wizz Air Abu Dhabi](/wiki/Wizz_Air_Abu_Dhabi "Wizz Air Abu Dhabi") and others. Ostafyevo International Airport caters primarily to business aviation.{#cite_ref-4airports_222-0}

Moscow's airports vary in distances from the MKAD beltway: Domodedovo is the farthest at 22 km (14 mi); Vnukovo is 11 km (7 mi); Sheremetyevo is 10 km (6 mi); and Ostafievo, the nearest, is about 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) from MKAD.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-4airports-222)^{#cite_ref-4airports_222-1}

There are a number of smaller airports close to Moscow (19 in Moscow Oblast) such as [Myachkovo Airport](/wiki/Myachkovo_Airport "Myachkovo Airport"), that are intended for private aircraft, helicopters and charters.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-223)^{#cite_ref-223}  

### Water {#Water}

Moscow has two passenger terminals, ([South River Terminal](/wiki/South_River_Terminal "South River Terminal") and [North River Terminal](/wiki/North_River_Terminal "North River Terminal")), on the river and regular ship routes and cruises along the [Moskva](/wiki/Moskva_River "Moskva River") and [Oka](/wiki/Oka_River "Oka River") rivers, which are used mostly for entertainment. The [North River Terminal](/wiki/North_River_Terminal "North River Terminal"), built in 1937, is the main hub for long-range river routes. There are three freight ports serving Moscow.  

### Sharing system {#Sharing_system}

See also: [Carsharing in Moscow](/wiki/Carsharing_in_Moscow "Carsharing in Moscow")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B5_%28%D0%AF%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81.%D0%94%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%B2%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B5_%28%D0%AF%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81.%D0%94%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%B2%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B5_(%D0%AF%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81.%D0%94%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%B2).jpg) As of 2020^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Moscow&action=edit)^, Moscow has the [largest fleet of carsharing vehicles](/wiki/Carsharing_in_Moscow "Carsharing in Moscow") in the world, with more than 30,000 cars.^[\[222\]](#cite_note-Carsharing-224)^

Moscow has different vehicle sharing options that are sponsored by the local government. There are several [car sharing](/wiki/Car_sharing "Car sharing") companies which are in charge of providing cars to the population. To drive the automobiles, the user has to book them through the app of the owning company. In 2018 the mayor [Sergey Sobyanin](/wiki/Sergey_Sobyanin "Sergey Sobyanin") said Moscow's car sharing system has become the biggest in Europe in terms of vehicle fleet.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-225)^ Every day about 25,000 people use this service. In the end of the same year Moscow carsharing became the second in the world in therms of fleet with 16.5K available vehicles.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-226)^ Another sharing system is [bike sharing](/wiki/Bike_sharing "Bike sharing") (*[Velobike](/wiki/Velobike "Velobike")* ) of a fleet formed by 3000 traditional and electrical bicycles.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-227)^ The *Delisamokat* is a new sharing service that provides electrical scooters.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-228)^{#cite_ref-228}  

### Future development {#Future_development}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0-%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B8_%282020%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0-%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B8_%282020%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE_%D0%B2_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0-%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B8_(2020).jpg) The 2020 development concept of [Moscow International Business Center](/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center "Moscow International Business Center") and its adjacent territory implies the construction of even more skyscrapers during the period of 2020--2027.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-229)^^[\[228\]](#cite_note-230)^

In 1992, the Moscow government began planning a projected new part of central Moscow, the [Moscow International Business Center](/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center "Moscow International Business Center"), with the goal of creating a zone, the first in Russia, and in all of Eastern Europe,^[\[229\]](#cite_note-231)^ that will combine business activity, living space and entertainment. Situated in [Presnensky District](/wiki/Presnensky_District "Presnensky District") and located at the Third Ring, the Moscow City area is under intense development. The construction of the MIBC takes place on the Krasnopresnenskaya embankment. The whole project takes up to one square kilometre (250 acres). The area is the only spot in downtown Moscow that can accommodate a project of this magnitude. Today, most of the buildings there are old factories and industrial complexes.{#cite_ref-231}

The [Federation Tower](/wiki/Federation_Tower "Federation Tower"), completed in 2016, is the [second-tallest building in Europe](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Europe "List of tallest buildings in Europe"). It is planned to include a [water park](/wiki/Water_park "Water park") and other recreational facilities; business, office, entertainment, and residential buildings, a transport network and a [new site for the Moscow government](/wiki/City_Hall_and_City_Duma "City Hall and City Duma"). The construction of four new metro stations in the territory has been completed, two of which have opened and two others are reserved for future metro lines crossing MIBC, some additional stations were planned.

* A rail shuttle service, directly connecting [MIBC](/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center "Moscow International Business Center") with the [Sheremetyevo International Airport](/wiki/Sheremetyevo_International_Airport "Sheremetyevo International Airport") is also planned.

Major thoroughfares through MIBC are the [Third Ring](/wiki/Third_Ring_Road_(Moscow) "Third Ring Road (Moscow)") and [Kutuzovsky Prospekt](/wiki/Kutuzovsky_Prospekt "Kutuzovsky Prospekt").

Three metro stations were initially planned for the [Filyovskaya Line](/wiki/Filyovskaya_Line "Filyovskaya Line"). The station Delovoi Tsentr opened in 2005 and was later renamed [Vystavochnaya](/wiki/Vystavochnaya "Vystavochnaya") in 2009. The branch extended to the [Mezhdunarodnaya](/wiki/Mezhdunarodnaya_(Moscow_Metro) "Mezhdunarodnaya (Moscow Metro)") station in 2006, and all work on the third station, Dorogomilovskaya (between [Kiyevskaya](/wiki/Kiyevskaya_(Filyovskaya) "Kiyevskaya (Filyovskaya)") and Delovoi Tsentr), has been postponed. There are plans to extend the branch as far as the [Savyolovskaya](/wiki/Savyolovskaya_(Serpukhovsko%E2%80%93Timiryazevskaya_line) "Savyolovskaya (Serpukhovsko–Timiryazevskaya line)") station, on the [Serpukhovsko-Timiryazevskaya Line](/wiki/Serpukhovsko-Timiryazevskaya_Line "Serpukhovsko-Timiryazevskaya Line").

The cellphone service provider MTS announced on 5 March 2021, that they would begin the country's first pilot [5G](/wiki/5G "5G") network in Moscow.^[\[230\]](#cite_note-232)^{#cite_ref-232}  

Media {#Media}
--------------

See also: [Media of Russia](/wiki/Media_of_Russia "Media of Russia")

Moscow is home to nearly all of Russia's nationwide [television networks](/wiki/Television_in_Russia "Television in Russia"), [radio stations](/wiki/Radio_station "Radio station"), newspapers, and magazines.

English-language media include *[The Moscow Times](/wiki/The_Moscow_Times "The Moscow Times")* and *[Moscow News](/wiki/Moscow_News "Moscow News")* , which are, respectively, the largest^[\[231\]](#cite_note-233)^ and oldest English-language weekly newspapers in all of Russia. *[Kommersant](/wiki/Kommersant "Kommersant")*, *[Vedomosti](/wiki/Vedomosti "Vedomosti")* and *[Novaya Gazeta](/wiki/Novaya_Gazeta "Novaya Gazeta")* are Russian-language media headquartered in Moscow. *Kommersant* and *Vedomosti* are among the country's leading and oldest Russian-language business newspapers.{#cite_ref-233}
